excerpts: Noodles were cooked perfectly and have that "al dente" crunch that is the epicenter of great wonton noodles.
The broth was flavorful, but not quite the best I've ever had.
Though the waitress had limited English for dine-in, she was really nice.
wonton noodles.author: Patricia N.
wonton noodles.review: Definitely can't beat a $4 bowl of shrimp wonton noodle soup for lunch on a cold rainy day.  The wontons were near perfect and the portion was plentiful.   Noodles were cooked perfectly and have that "al dente" crunch that is the epicenter of great wonton noodles.  The broth was flavorful, but not quite the best I've ever had.  Though the waitress had limited English for dine-in, she was really nice.

excerpts: I was after the delicious duck/wonton noodles.
Extremely generous servings of duck, I expected like 4 pieces for the price, but they gave almost more than I could eat!
wonton noodles.author: Amanda C.
wonton noodles.review:
Came here on a Sunday at noon and it was packed, but the turnover is so fast that it took about 15 mins to get seated even with a few parties in front of us. 

I was after the delicious duck/wonton noodles. Extremely generous servings of duck, I expected like 4 pieces for the price, but they gave almost more than I could eat! At least 8 pieces.

The surprise of the day though was the $3 porridge. We ordered 2 bowls, thinking it would be personal sized bowls at $3... but turned out to be LARGE bowls, the size of the noodle bowls! We took almost all of this home because that one porridge bowl serves about 8 personal sized bowls of porridge! Amazing!!! Talk about great value. 

Also the da dou miao (veggies) was cooked nice and garlicky. We didn't really order it, the waiter forcefully recommended/ordered it for us, and we were too noob to decline. But in the end I'm glad we didn't.

excerpts:
Uber cheap and pretty tasty roasted duck wonton noodles.
However, service is super slow, esp for a Chinese eatery. 
Hence the long wait.
Took them 20++ mins to get me my dish
wonton noodles.author: Jocelyn L.
wonton noodles.review:
Uber cheap and pretty tasty roasted duck wonton noodles.
However, service is super slow, esp for a Chinese eatery. 
Hence the long wait.
Took them 20++ mins to get me my dish

excerpts: The roast pork wonton noodles were cheap ($6.25 including tax) and generously portioned.
Rice and noodle dishes were even cheaper and looked just as large.
Still, taste was just average.
Moreover, the roast pork was very fatty and some of the wontons had inedible bits in them (likely pieces of shrimp shells).
Overall, meh on a quality scale.
wonton noodles.author: Vincent L.
wonton noodles.review:
Kam Po draws a steady stream of Chinatown locals who get fresh barbecued meats to go. As a dine-in place, I can get over the grungy lack of superficial cleanliness (sadly typical of many U.S. Chinatown restaurants, as I'm used to seeing), so I decided to give this place a try based on the high average Yelp rating. 

The roast pork wonton noodles were cheap ($6.25 including tax) and generously portioned. Rice and noodle dishes were even cheaper and looked just as large. Still, taste was just average. Moreover, the roast pork was very fatty and some of the wontons had inedible bits in them (likely pieces of shrimp shells). Overall, meh on a quality scale. To their credit, service was fast and courteous given that I can speak Cantonese. 

Grab your order of barbecued, custom-butchered meats to go, for lunch or dinner at home. If you're conscious about the fat, make sure to trim it out on your own.

excerpts: and I have it over rice or wonton noodles.
wonton noodles.author: Rosie W.
wonton noodles.review:
I call this Chinese soul food. 

I used to come here alot when I was younger. There's been so many owners since then but the quality of the food remains good. It's a little run down, it can be dirty (just wash the utensils in the hot tea) and the waitresses can be a bit rude, but I swear the food is good! I love their meats - roasted duck is my favorite and I have it over rice or wonton noodles. If you feel like having more than one type of meat, you can can order it that way too - like roasted duck and soy sauce chicken over rice. They're not shady with the portions and it just delicious. Easy, quick, delicious meal.

Please try not to get grossed out with how run down/dirty it is! Give it a chance if you haven't been.

excerpts: There are the tradition wonton noodles with ur choosing of a meat .
Apointer if u get bbq items on soup dish always ask for it on dish, its a much better cut.
This place is really inexpensive and yes its cash only and they close around 7pm.
wonton noodles.author: Jorm K.
wonton noodles.review:
3 n half stars

Hmm this place is your typically hole in the wall of chinatown. So the place is a little greasy and grimey. The Chinese bbq is above par roast pig bbq pork and duck. For those who are adventurist there are pig intestines , bbq chicken livers, and pork stomach stew in soy sauce. There are the tradition wonton noodles with ur choosing of a meat . Apointer if u get bbq items on soup dish always ask for it on dish, its a much better cut. This place is really inexpensive and yes its cash only and they close around 7pm.

excerpts: Roast duck over rice, duck wonton soup and prawn with egg chow fun are all good choices.
Everything is also inexpensive.
Unlike many of the butcher shops in Chinatown, Kam Po does not skimp out on the meat.
wonton.author: Philip M.
wonton.review:
everything is so darn good here.

Kam Po Kitchen doesn't serve up Michelin-standard cooking, but it serves up big hearty portions of delicious Hong Kong style dishes. There are a lot of tables within the restaurant but all the tables are very close to each other. Be prepared to share some personal space! Kam Po Kitchen offers sit-down meal service or a take-out line for those who wish to bring home roast duck, soy sauce chicken or any meat of the sort. 

I have tried a number of the dishes offered here. Roast duck over rice, duck wonton soup and prawn with egg chow fun are all good choices. Everything is also inexpensive. Unlike many of the butcher shops in Chinatown, Kam Po does not skimp out on the meat. I have tried the prawn with egg chow fun dish throughout many Chinese restaurants in Chinatown, and the one here is hands down the best. 

Many of the staff members here don't speak English. Two of the female staff speaks English and provides good service though. The only thing that irks me is that the dining tables are always so greasy or oily from a lack of quality deep cleaning. This is a very popular lunch spot for locals in Chinatown. Kam Po is great for your stomach and easy on your wallet and it's definitely one of my favorite lunch spots in Chinatown! CASH ONLY!

excerpts: Arrived here because I had a real craving for wonton soup.
So much so that I couldn't proceed any further with my day before satiating my craving.
I've been here for take out of their roasted meats, as well as their beef chow fun.
wonton.author: Lori N.
wonton.review:
This is a dive, a genuine hole in the wall.  With a capital D, capital I, capital V, capital E.  This no frills spot on the edge of Chinatown is known for its BBQ  and roasted Chinese meats. It's totally a quick, cheap eats spot.  

Arrived here because I had a real craving for wonton soup.  So much so that I couldn't proceed any further with my day before satiating my craving.  I've been here for take out of their roasted meats, as well as their beef chow fun.  The chow fun here is always nicely wok fried, and the noodles never clump or stick together. 

I heard this place served very generous portions, so that piqued my interest.  You know the saying though, "The proof is in the pudding".  Well, my response to that has always been, "Serve up the pudding!".  Show me!  Prove it to me!  And not with words.  Talk is cheap...Well, they did.

I was served a huge bowl of roasted duck with wontons and rice noodles, for just $8.00 pre-tip.  The massive portion of roasted duck was very meaty and moist.  Most importantly, unlike many noodle joints that literally drown their meats in the broth, Kam Po perfectly "floated" their meat atop a massive mound of rice noodles.  This kept the skin of the duck perfectly crispy.  This was worth the entire dish, my friend.  

The won tons, filled with pork and shrimp were fine. 

The amount of rice noodles were literally ginormous.  In fact, I would've preferred 50% less. Did I just say that?  Yes, simply because rice noodles tend to absorb liquid like a sponge, and by the time I finished only about 20% of the dish, I was left with gloppy rice noodles, and barely any remaining broth.  However, if you like huge portions, this is for you.

Again, this is a DIVE.  If one desires to dine here, one must remember that a nice ambiance is obsolete.  While I was here, an elderly Chinese gentleman was literally yelling on his phone in Chinese during the entire course of my lunch.  The other elderly Chinese customers also seemed perturbed.  However, this apparent soliloquy seemed to go completely unnoticed by the staff.  Just another day here, it seems...

excerpts: Wonton soup, rice plate with roasted pork were pretty straight forward, just tastier than most.
Maybe I lucked out with super fatty pieces of pork, but the white pieces weren't dry.
wonton.author: Sheewon B.
wonton.review:
If you can get over the dried pieces of food on your utensils, layer of unidentified oil on top of your scalding hot tea, and other cleanliness question marks, this place is pretty darn solid for hole-in-the-wall Chinese food. Just don't grab the underside of the table with your bare hands to pull yourself closer to it. 

Wonton soup, rice plate with roasted pork were pretty straight forward, just tastier than most. Maybe I lucked out with super fatty pieces of pork, but the white pieces weren't dry. A feat, when it looks like the hanging pig from which they cut your meat looks like it's been there for a while. 

Maybe that's it. It looks like just another Chinese food place, but they have lots of customers.

excerpts: We ordered a Hainanese Chicken and Rice dish as well as a Roast Duck Wonton Noodle Soup bowl.
The wonton soup bowl was a generous portion size, with a large amount of roast duck and several large fresh tasting wontons.
The Hainanese Chicken was tender and the green onion topping was flavorful.
Both were excellent and at a very good price.
The restaurant also served complimentary hot tea.
Service was efficient and the restaurant was clean.
Plenty of indoor seating.
Parking can be difficult to find however.
Overall definitely worth a visit.
The wonton soup bowl was a generous portion size, with a large amount of roast duck and several large fresh tasting wontons.
The Hainanese Chicken was tender and the green onion topping was flavorful.
Both were excellent and at a very good price.
The restaurant also served complimentary hot tea.
Service was efficient and the restaurant was clean.
Plenty of indoor seating.
Parking can be difficult to find however.
Overall definitely worth a visit.
wonton.author: Tina D.
wonton.review: Came here around 10:30am on a cold gloomy day looking for some comfort food. We ordered a Hainanese Chicken and Rice dish as well as a Roast Duck Wonton Noodle Soup bowl. The wonton soup bowl was a generous portion size, with a large amount of roast duck and several large fresh tasting wontons. The Hainanese Chicken was tender and the green onion topping was flavorful. Both were excellent and at a very good price. The restaurant also served complimentary hot tea. Service was efficient and the restaurant was clean. Plenty of indoor seating. Parking can be difficult to find however. Overall definitely worth a visit.

excerpts: The menu is your typical Cantonese style which means it a gazillion choices ranging from wonton noodle soup, porridge, rice plates and pan fried noodles to curries and snacks.
wonton.author: Ahmad J.
wonton.review:
Kam Po Kitchen is a Cantonese restaurant that is outside the tourist circuit in Chinatown but it looks any other restaurant in the heart of Chinatown with various BBQ meats hanging from the window. The menu is your typical Cantonese style which means it a gazillion choices ranging from wonton noodle soup, porridge, rice plates and pan fried noodles to curries and snacks.

The BBQ meats in the window looked good so I decided to get a 2 Item with rice ($8.30) combo to-go and went for the soy chicken and duck. Payment was cash only. I got a huge container that was filled to the brim with good quality cuts of both chicken and duck. I mean their serving size is almost double of what you will get at Yee's which is in the heart of Chinatown. The duck here actually had some meat on the bone and did not consist of all fat that you get elsewhere. I've come back here a couple of times and the quality has been consistent across visits. I haven't tried anything from their huge menu but if it is anything like their BBQ meats, I think it would be really good. Kam Po Kitchen gets a thumbs-up from me.

excerpts: My go-to items are their chow fun, roast duck, roast pork, and wonton soup.
wonton.author: Camille L.
wonton.review:
I LOVE this place. 

It's very convenient to call your order in ten minutes prior, illegally park, then run in to grab your bags of enough food to survive for the next two days, all
for something like $20! 

My go-to items are their chow fun, roast duck, roast pork, and wonton soup.

Sweet customer service goes a long way, too.

excerpts: We ordered the shrimp wonton, yum!!!!
The duck was to die for!
And the fried rice and delicious.
Best of all: we only spent $17!!!!
It is dirt cheap, especially by San Fran standards!!!
wonton.author: Frances R.
wonton.review: This gem is located outside of the busy tourists area. No one speaks English, the floor and tables are dirty, but the food was phenomenal! We ordered the shrimp wonton, yum!!!! The duck was to die for! And the fried rice and delicious. Best of all: we only spent $17!!!! It is dirt cheap, especially by San Fran standards!!!

excerpts: I slurp down their beef stew wonton soup on 5 mins and ordered a rice place with 2 bbq items to go and half duck ohhhh and half lb of beef tendon.
Don't judge me who doesn't love a skinny girl that can eat?
wonton.author: Kris J.
wonton.review:
Food is heaven! I had preggo craving so caught a uber here. I slurp down their beef stew wonton soup on 5 mins and ordered a rice place with 2 bbq items to go and half duck ohhhh and half lb of beef tendon. Don't judge me who doesn't love a skinny girl that can eat? Lol

Cash only. 

Customer service was ok. The chef/butcher was mean, I actually wanted some cuttlefish too he said I have to buy the whole thing or nothing at all  I know I got a big appetite but I can't eat that much now... overall good experience. Brings back childhood memory like 15 years ago when I lived in CT and used to do laundry with my mom across the street and eat here to wait for our laundry. Awwwww

excerpts: I get the combo - duck with bbq pork over rice and sometimes, I get the roast duck wonton rice noodles.
Come and visit soon
wonton.author: Jsphn T.
wonton.review:
This is gets busy during lunchtime or else you have to stand there and wait. The hot food to go line is decent.
The menu prices is reasonable . I get the combo - duck with bbq pork over rice and sometimes, I get the roast duck wonton rice noodles. Come and visit soon

excerpts: Their congee was only $3.50 and the roast duck and wonton noodle soup about $7.
I mean, geez, we were stuffed with a total check amount of less than $12!
wonton.author: Christina L.
wonton.review:
I will admit, for value and convenience Kam Po cannot be beat! They were open at 9:30 am on a Saturday when I woke up in a daze with a hankering for noodle soup. Their congee was only $3.50 and the roast duck and wonton noodle soup about $7. I mean, geez, we were stuffed with a total check amount of less than $12! For these reasons, I do recommend Kam Po and will probably be back...only when it's the only option available.

The preserved duck egg and pork had good flavor but the pork had that weird off taste of lower end Chinese restaurants. The duck was good but the noodle soup and wontons were otherwise lacking in flavor.

Great stop to stop by when you're looking for a quick, cheap bite, otherwise there are definitely other options nearby.

excerpts: The BBQ, wonton noodle soup, rice noodle soup, fried noodles... everything.
Everything is good.
wonton.author: Lauren J.
wonton.review:
I have been eating at this place since I was a child and it has never disappointed me. If you're looking for good portions, cheap price, and good food, this is the place to go. 

If you're looking for a spacious and clean restaurant however, this is not the place to go. It is your typical hole in the wall (ish) Chinese restaurant where people come to eat and leave, but it's always busy so you know it's good.

The BBQ, wonton noodle soup, rice noodle soup, fried noodles... everything. Everything is good.

excerpts: This was my first time here, and I ordered the duck wonton soup and chicken fried rice.
First off, probably the best sized portions for the price in the city.
The fried rice was awesome, but the duck was cold and the soup was 3/4 rice noodles.
I want to come back for another dish, because I really want to like this restaurant more than I do.

My review is
Flexible to be changed.
wonton.author: Ross S.
wonton.review:
This was my first time here, and I ordered the duck wonton soup and chicken fried rice. First off, probably the best sized portions for the price in the city. The fried rice was awesome, but the duck was cold and the soup was 3/4 rice noodles. I want to come back for another dish, because I really want to like this restaurant more than I do. My review is
Flexible to be changed.

excerpts: We had their roast duck, roast pork, pork fried rice, shrimp fried rice, shrimp wonton soup, and their Chinese broccoli.
Everything was delicious!
For a party of 6, we only paid $57.
wonton.author: Anna D.
wonton.review:
If you want to dive into the Chinese culture and surroundings, you must come to Kam Po to eat. We first came here about 10 years ago and have been waiting for the day when we would come back to eat here. It is exactly as I remembered. 

It's a little intimidating when you first walk in here. The customers are mostly local Chinese and a few others who have braved the parking and the streets to try out their food. Don't expect 5 star dining or service. This is a no frills place - you come in, sit down, order and eat. Cash only, by the way. 

We stayed a total of 5 days here in San Francisco, and of all the places we've eaten, this is the one we talked about the most. We had their roast duck, roast pork, pork fried rice, shrimp fried rice, shrimp wonton soup, and their Chinese broccoli. Everything was delicious! For a party of 6, we only paid $57. Most, if not all of their dishes are $6-$8.

After returning from our trip, we were craving Kam Po food, so we ordered from our go-to Chinese restaurant, and nothing comes close. I guess we're going to have to wait for another trip to SF for a visit!

excerpts: Roast duck wonton egg noodle soup is grub.
The garlic pea sprouts is really tasty.
wonton.author: Andy V.
wonton.review: Nice little roast duck and pork restaurant. Roast duck wonton egg noodle soup is grub. The garlic pea sprouts is really tasty. Roast pork is just average. It's a tiny place but service is fast. They only accept cash.

excerpts: I had wonton noodle soup for $4.25.
And I was reasonably full afterwards.
Where can you get a meal in San Francisco for less than 4.50?
Granted there is virtually no service,decor, or hipsters around but this was fine for me.
I've been looking for a place where I can get decent meal for under 10 bucks
and I finally found it.
I'm not saying the food was life-changing-but it was wonderful for the price point.
And this certainly a place that I will be back.
wonton.author: Robert C.
wonton.review: This place is how San Francisco use to do it! A local no frills cash only Chinese place with reasonable prices and good portions. I had wonton noodle soup for $4.25. And I was reasonably full afterwards. Where can you get a meal in San Francisco for less than 4.50? Granted there is virtually no service,decor, or hipsters around but this was fine for me. I've been looking for a place where I can get decent meal for under 10 bucks and I finally found it. I'm not saying the food was life-changing-but it was wonderful for the price point. And this certainly a place that I will be back.

excerpts: Definitely can't beat a $4 bowl of shrimp wonton noodle soup for lunch on a cold rainy day.
The wontons were near perfect and the portion was plentiful.
Noodles were cooked perfectly and have that "al dente" crunch that is the epicenter of great wonton noodles.
The broth was flavorful, but not quite the best I've ever had.
Though the waitress had limited English for dine-in, she was really nice.
wonton.author: Patricia N.
wonton.review: Definitely can't beat a $4 bowl of shrimp wonton noodle soup for lunch on a cold rainy day.  The wontons were near perfect and the portion was plentiful.   Noodles were cooked perfectly and have that "al dente" crunch that is the epicenter of great wonton noodles.  The broth was flavorful, but not quite the best I've ever had.  Though the waitress had limited English for dine-in, she was really nice.

excerpts: I ordered the roasted duck wonton soup.
The wonton was decent but not to my liking.
The duck was generous and flavorful.
There were pieces of cabbage in it.
They ran out of chicken feet which made me sad.
I also got the BBQ duck and pork over rice.
The portion was insanely huge.
It was a ton of food for such a small small price.
The food tastes as good as Macau-so incredibly authentic and delicious.
I will have to come back and bring the whole gang.
wonton.author: Elle R.
wonton.review: Holiest hole in the wall. Makes me think of Macau. They only take cash. The noodles are fresh and homemade. I ordered the roasted duck wonton soup. The wonton was decent but not to my liking. The duck was generous and flavorful. There were pieces of cabbage in it. They ran out of chicken feet which made me sad. I also got the BBQ duck and pork over rice. The portion was insanely huge. It was a ton of food for such a small small price. The food tastes as good as Macau-so incredibly authentic and delicious. I will have to come back and bring the whole gang.

excerpts: The wonton soup with roast duck was okay.
Good wontons.
Okay roast duck.
wonton.author: Jean K.
wonton.review: The bbq pork is still the way to go. I know their roast pork is supposed to be famous but at Saturday lunchtime it was not great - dry meat, hard skin (not crispy hard, but hard hard). The wonton soup with roast duck was okay. Good wontons. Okay roast duck.

excerpts: Ordered the roast duck in wonton noodle soup ($7) but unfortunately 10 minutes into making it they told me they didn't have roast duck anymore and asked if roast pork was fine.
It wasn't really the best alternative but it was still good too.
The soup broth and wontons really made up for it.
wonton.author: Linda X.
wonton.review:
CASH ONLY

This is one of my favorite spots for cheap Chinese food! Don't expect anything fancy or the service to be overly friendly and attentive. Yes the server throws menus at you when you sit and you might have to flag them down if you want something but it's all part of the local Chinatown experience. It's more about good cheap food in large quantities.

Ordered the porridge with preserved egg ($3.50). It was served in a massive bowl and was enough for 2 people by itself. Personally I LOVE this dish. It feels so homey and filling. I took my friend who had never had preserved egg before and he really didn't like it so it's definitely an acquired taste.

Ordered the roast duck in wonton noodle soup ($7) but unfortunately 10 minutes into making it they told me they didn't have roast duck anymore and asked if roast pork was fine. It wasn't really the best alternative but it was still good too. The soup broth and wontons really made up for it. You get this giant bowl enough for 2 people on its own!

Overall go for the food and prices not the service.

excerpts: We decided to do family style dinner, so we ordered wonton soup, seafood tofu soup, salted fish fried rice, pan fried house noodles, beef chow fun, roasted pork belly, Garlic Chinese broccoli, garlic water spinach and fish with sweet corn over rice, all to share amongst each other.
Everything was really good and our tummies were satisfied!
The dish that stood out the most to me was the fish w sweet corn!
wonton.author: Lihz P.
wonton.review:
Fairly cheap. Big portions. Quick service! Always packed! So not really great for big groups unless you're willing to wait..

Came in today with my family (party of 10) around 2:30pm and there were no tables open so we waited a good 20-25 minutes before a table opened up. The staff was very nice and quick to let us know it'll be a while until we were seated which was no problem because only half of us were there first. 
--Minus 1 star for all the people who came in after us and seated themselves at random tables instead of waiting to be seated.--
By the time the rest of the party was there it only took us about 5 more minutes until we were seated.

Onto the food... We decided to do family style dinner, so we ordered wonton soup, seafood tofu soup, salted fish fried rice, pan fried house noodles, beef chow fun, roasted pork belly, Garlic Chinese broccoli, garlic water spinach and fish with sweet corn over rice, all to share amongst each other. Everything was really good and our tummies were satisfied! The dish that stood out the most to me was the fish w sweet corn! It sounded weird at first, but don't knock it til you try it!

Obviously, since they sell fresh af Chinese bbq in store as well, we had to buy some to bring home for family dinner! Sadly they didn't have oxtail.. But we ordered roast duck, roast pork, bbq pork, pork intestines, chicken feet, &soy sauce chicken. When we got home tonight, we had a feast! Ate all that with side of baguettes & soy sauce, Vietnamese style! 

This is always my family's go to lunch spot when we're in Chinatown SF. We'll be back soon!

excerpts: You can also get the roast duck in a bowl of won ton noodles - you get a lot of duck and wonton dumplings, but the skin isn't crispy..
wonton.author: Lydia N.
wonton.review:
Classic Chinatown! I didn't know places like this still existed! (Certainly not that I've seen Seattle). Everything on the menu is ~ $7 or less. Cash only. Giant portions. They speak Canto. There's hanging roast meats (duck & pork) in the window. So many soup noodles. 

Came here for dinner seeking some roast duck. We left stuffed with duck, noodles, bitter melon, BBQ pork (char siu), wontons... The roast duck over rice is a good deal. Not only does it feel like you're served half a duck, but it's also really tasty! The flavor seemed pretty great and the meat was juicy.  The skin wasn't super crisp and on the fattier side, but I kinda like it that way. You can also get the roast duck in a bowl of won ton noodles - you get a lot of duck and wonton dumplings, but the skin isn't crispy.. the addition of won ton dumplings (they're just ok, a little starchy and dense) isn't worth soggy duck.  

Char siu (BBQ pork) was definitely homemade and not cloyingly sweet - which I really appreciated. It also isn't bright red like you might find at other restaurants. What you end up with is a natural looking savory BBQ pork, with a hint of sweetness. It's also a bit fatty. Yum!

Veggies - the garlic green beans aren't as garlicky or salty or fried as other places, but it's a simple dish. It's still a bit oily, so I don't know if you actually feel healthier for eating these vegs.  The bitter melon was pretty good though - if you enjoy bitter melon. I found it pretty mild and simply seasoned here.

excerpts: We had wonton, noodle, and beef tender tendons and bittermelon with black bean sauce beef and chow fun.
Yes this place is cramped and tsbles are a bit greasy.
But it is an experience.
You get served quickly, you eat, and you don't lounge around.
So much to eat but so little room in the tummy.
The duck looked good.
wonton.author: Helen L.
wonton.review: They are still the cheapest, best with big portions.  The guy next to us had a meal with rice, soup, bittermelon and chicken for 6.00 including tax.  Our meal total was 14.00 for 2 and leftovers for another meal.  Go figure.  We had wonton, noodle, and beef tender tendons and bittermelon with black bean sauce beef and chow fun.  Yes this place is cramped and tsbles are a bit greasy.  But it is an experience.  You get served quickly, you eat, and you don't lounge around.  So much to eat but so little room in the tummy. The duck looked good.

excerpts: I was after the delicious duck/wonton noodles.
Extremely generous servings of duck, I expected like 4 pieces for the price, but they gave almost more than I could eat!
wonton.author: Amanda C.
wonton.review:
Came here on a Sunday at noon and it was packed, but the turnover is so fast that it took about 15 mins to get seated even with a few parties in front of us. 

I was after the delicious duck/wonton noodles. Extremely generous servings of duck, I expected like 4 pieces for the price, but they gave almost more than I could eat! At least 8 pieces.

The surprise of the day though was the $3 porridge. We ordered 2 bowls, thinking it would be personal sized bowls at $3... but turned out to be LARGE bowls, the size of the noodle bowls! We took almost all of this home because that one porridge bowl serves about 8 personal sized bowls of porridge! Amazing!!! Talk about great value. 

Also the da dou miao (veggies) was cooked nice and garlicky. We didn't really order it, the waiter forcefully recommended/ordered it for us, and we were too noob to decline. But in the end I'm glad we didn't.

excerpts: Other popular dishes include chow mein and chow fun, lo mein, congee (rice porridge), wonton noodle soup with a variety of meats and soups that usually includes lettuce and some type of meat, meat and vegetable rice plates and seasonal vegetables.
The shrimp wonton noodle soup, $3.25, had great texture and good flavor in its ingredients and nearly met my high standards for this dish.
The gumdrop shaped, succulent shrimp wontons were made with whole shrimp and complemented with a mild soup broth and tasty wide rice noodles that were velvety soft and luxuriously smooth.
The broth could have had more flavor.
Their shrimp wonton noodle soup, in particular, is worth repeated visits here.
wonton.author: Andrew K.
wonton.review:
In a city nearly defined in its culinary circles for the endless array of choices when it comes to inexpensive, very good Chinese food, Kam Po Kitchen deserves to be mentioned in this conversation. 

Dingy hole-in-the-wall restaurants throughout Chinatown, the Richmond and Sunset districts that specialize in Cantonese cuisine seem to be synonymous for authentic, cheap, very tasty Chinese food in generous portions.

Chief among my Cantonese favorite dishes are the Char Siu (roasted or barbecued meats) that always consists of duck, chicken and pork. Other popular dishes include chow mein and chow fun, lo mein, congee (rice porridge), wonton noodle soup with a variety of meats and soups that usually includes lettuce and some type of meat, meat and vegetable rice plates and seasonal vegetables.

Kam Po Kitchen had a pretty comprehensive menu list and is known for preparing most of these traditional and uniquely flavored dishes exceptionally well, including what many say are some of the best Chinese noodle soup in the city.

We reluctantly chose lighter dishes this evening because of our prior dinner reservation at Tony's Pizza Napoletana just a block away and dropped in looking for something to tie us down until then.

The noodle soup dishes, we figured, were a must-try and not too heavy. A friend also ordered a plate of steamed offals that we could share.

The mixed innards (offal), $3.95, were a good mix of steamed pig ears, intestines, stomach, gizzards and liver sparsely layered with a soy sauce and sesame oil mix. It was a rich and uniquely flavored, traditional dish that made for a great starter or appetizer.

The beef tendon noodle soup, $3.75, was a very good choice because they use the peripheral parts of the tendon which carried bits of flesh and fat, giving it a real beefy flavor and a meaty depth. The stringy egg noodles went perfectly with the hearty chunks of tendon and really soaked up the flavor of the delicately seasoned beef broth.

The shrimp wonton noodle soup, $3.25, had great texture and good flavor in its ingredients and nearly met my high standards for this dish. The gumdrop shaped, succulent shrimp wontons were made with whole shrimp and complemented with a mild soup broth and tasty wide rice noodles that were velvety soft and luxuriously smooth. The broth could have had more flavor. Otherwise, it would have been prepared to perfection.

Most dishes fall under $5. I hope to return and try their Char Siu that they are widely known for to gain a broader perspective on the food here. Upon my one visit, I felt fairly certain Kam Po ranks among the best Cantonese style noodle soup restaurants I have tried. Their shrimp wonton noodle soup, in particular, is worth repeated visits here.

excerpts: $7 for a bowl of bbq pork and shrimp wonton with noodles wins me over.
Portions are generous.
Expect dirty hole in the wall noodle shop that will fill your happy tummy and you will not be disappointed.
wonton.author: Richman L.
wonton.review: $7 for a bowl of bbq pork and shrimp wonton with noodles wins me over. Portions are generous. Expect dirty hole in the wall noodle shop that will fill your happy tummy and you will not be disappointed.

excerpts: Had the Shrimp Wonton and 炒麵. Both very good and not at all oily.
Service is nice as well.
wonton.author: Amanda L.
wonton.review: So good and so cheap! Fresh noodles. Had the Shrimp Wonton and 炒麵. Both very good and not at all oily. Service is nice as well.

excerpts: We had mustard  greens, soy sauce  chicken and duck wonton noodle soup.
All were fine, with the wontons in the soup the best.
On the other hand, all that, with tea and rice for less than  $25 before tip.
Who can complain?
wonton.author: David R.
wonton.review: Nothing wrong with Kam Po, but I just can't go all the way to four stars.  We had mustard  greens, soy sauce  chicken and duck wonton noodle soup.  All were fine, with the wontons in the soup the best.   On the other hand, all that, with tea and rice for less than  $25 before tip.  Who can complain?

excerpts: The wonton soup was a light broth with wonton filled with mushrooms and possibly meat.
wonton.author: Marc M.
wonton.review:
The very windy interior is not the best during cold months. We dropped during the evening when it was a little chilly to find their door propped open and vented windows open as if it were a hot summer's day. Good grief, I'm surprised they can even stand the hilly draft blowing napkins on the floor and chilling you to the bone. They did eventually close the door, but it's still a cold restaurant, so don't how up without warm clothes!

Crsipy roast pork was dry and chewy, and the crispy skin was soggy and flavorless. It was actually kind of bad. I would not recommend this.

The roast duck had an excellent flavor, albeit on the salty side. A shame it was a little bony too. As far as the skin and meat go however, it was tasty.

The wonton soup was a light broth with wonton filled with mushrooms and possibly meat. They had a slight woody flavor that we weren't super excited about, but they are ok.

Rice is a ridiculously cheap, light, and flavorless affair. Unless you are jonesing for rice, this is not the place to get it. Flip side is that they I've you a big bowl of the crap for $1.

excerpts: I got the duck wonton noodle soup and it was amazing.
wonton.author: Fiona Y.
wonton.review:
It took 15 minutes to take my order with 3 people working because the lady ahead ordered 3 ducks and was super picky about it but that's not their fault I guess.

I got the duck wonton noodle soup and it was amazing. Silky, chicken broth with chewy egg noodles, giant meat filled wontons, and succulent roast duck. The soy chicken over rice was also one of the best things I've ever eaten in Chinatown. The chicken was so tender and flavorful, like it had been marinated and roasted all day. Must try the pork next time. 

If you're a carnivore, this is a must try.

excerpts: Wonton Soup
- This is ONE serving which is big enough for 2-3 people to share it!
wonton.author: Jennifer S.
wonton.review:
I friggin' loveeee this place!! After my friend recommended this as a "default" of his, I just had to try it for myself!

Here's a tip:
- If you're dining in, you just seat yourself and they'll bring you menus.
- If you're taking out, you get in line at the door.

I ended up in line when I wanted to dine in. Fail whale. But they were nice enough about it :)

We ordered:
Chicken on Rice - Yes, this was kind of amazing. Its the hunan kind of chicken..and it was super juicy and tender. yumyumyummmmm~
Duck - You CAN"T do duck wrong in Chinatown. Seriously..plus it was only $13 for the duck. AMAZING.
Wonton Soup - This is ONE serving which is big enough for 2-3 people to share it! PERFECT with some rice and duck...mmmm..

Wonderful place to catch a quick bite. Don't expect anything fancy or service to be spectacular..but DO expect some really good comfort food.

excerpts:
Uber cheap and pretty tasty roasted duck wonton noodles.
However, service is super slow, esp for a Chinese eatery. 
Hence the long wait.
Took them 20++ mins to get me my dish
wonton.author: Jocelyn L.
wonton.review:
Uber cheap and pretty tasty roasted duck wonton noodles.
However, service is super slow, esp for a Chinese eatery. 
Hence the long wait.
Took them 20++ mins to get me my dish

excerpts: Shrimp Wonton Noodle
Soup - About this time our server pushed together another 2 top table against ours.
With just the 2 of us ordering so much food, shit just got real.
wonton.author: Alexander C.
wonton.review:
Seriously amazing down home Chinese cookery! There's not much to be said about the decor, its barely clean but if you look beyond the greasy tables and the stacks of old newspapers you'll find one that Kam Po is probably one of the best Chinese places I've tried in Chinatown. 

1/2 Roast Duck - Im a huge addict to great roasted duck, from the crispy skin to the moist fatty meat, there's just something comforting about that smell of five spice that sort of reminds me of autumn. KPK nailed this down! 

Small Roast Pork - Small really wasn't all that small. Probably a good half pound of killer roast pork that came with rice and a side of pickled cabbage. My thoughts, rich fatty pork, I mean come on, how can it be so good? Even the crunchy skin didn't stand a chance against me and my love for pork.

Shrimp Wonton Noodle Soup - About this time our server pushed together another 2 top table against ours. With just the 2 of us ordering so much food, shit just got real. The soup had a good flavor and the chewy shrimp wontons were even better once I adorned them with a whole lot of chili paste. 

Beef Chow Fun - Greasy beefy and awesome! The noodles had a good amount of char and smoke flavor from a wok that's hot as hell. One thing to note is that the portion sizes here are huge and very sharable. 

At this point we were starting to hit the wall. We had chowed like it was our last meal though considering how hung over we were, it might as well have been. With this meal sitting in our bellies our hangovers started to subside. So another insight about KPK, a definite hang over cure.

excerpts: we came cause I saw shrimp only wonton noodle soup hong kong style which is hard to find, 99% of places use shrimp and pork in their shrimp wonton noodle.
wonton.author: NYSD G.
wonton.review:
we came cause I saw shrimp only wonton noodle soup hong kong style which is hard to find, 99% of places use shrimp and pork in their shrimp wonton noodle. the other 1% is 3000 miles away from NY Noodletown. 

not as amazing as NY Noodletown in the broth but no one is. also the noodles while al dente wasn't as light and chewy as NYN. the duck while good was on the salty side cause of the dripping sauce and to many cuts with no meat. also ordered their char siu pork which was disappointing. it wasn't a deep dark red more light red in color and it had an affect on flavor. also very few cuts had the dark red crusty ring around it which also ruined a bite. it would take me three weeks later to rectify my taste buds with proper char siu in the most unlikely place.

excerpts: We had the bbq duck wonton egg noodle soup, soy sauce chicken fun noodle soup, Chinese broccoli, two meat rice platter.
All were delicious.
Easy 5 stars if it weren't for the rude gesture of leaving a tip when we haven't yet left....
wonton.author: Jo J.
wonton.review: Yummmmy. We had the bbq duck wonton egg noodle soup, soy sauce chicken fun noodle soup, Chinese broccoli, two meat rice platter. All were delicious. Easy 5 stars if it weren't for the rude gesture of leaving a tip when we haven't yet left....

excerpts: The roast pork wonton noodles were cheap ($6.25 including tax) and generously portioned.
Rice and noodle dishes were even cheaper and looked just as large.
Still, taste was just average.
Moreover, the roast pork was very fatty and some of the wontons had inedible bits in them (likely pieces of shrimp shells).
Overall, meh on a quality scale.
wonton.author: Vincent L.
wonton.review:
Kam Po draws a steady stream of Chinatown locals who get fresh barbecued meats to go. As a dine-in place, I can get over the grungy lack of superficial cleanliness (sadly typical of many U.S. Chinatown restaurants, as I'm used to seeing), so I decided to give this place a try based on the high average Yelp rating. 

The roast pork wonton noodles were cheap ($6.25 including tax) and generously portioned. Rice and noodle dishes were even cheaper and looked just as large. Still, taste was just average. Moreover, the roast pork was very fatty and some of the wontons had inedible bits in them (likely pieces of shrimp shells). Overall, meh on a quality scale. To their credit, service was fast and courteous given that I can speak Cantonese. 

Grab your order of barbecued, custom-butchered meats to go, for lunch or dinner at home. If you're conscious about the fat, make sure to trim it out on your own.

excerpts: Beef stew wonton soup (4.75) .
Very good and tasty.
Large portion.
Soup had a wonderful taste to it as did the added meat and noodles including the wonton.
wonton.author: Steven G.
wonton.review:
Took my wife and a visiting friend from Ohio to Kam Po yesterday.  This was my second visit. 

I ordered a half duck. I will confirm that this was the best duck I ever ate anywhere. Large portions of meat and the outside was prepared in a way that was tastefully superior to any I ever had. Only $6.50!  Five stars for the duck. 

Pork fried rice was good but not exceptional. (About $5.55)  Regular size portion. Three stars.

Beef over rice. Large portion of that with so much beef. (4.65) Good taste. Three and half stars.

Beef chow fun. (4.65) Wonderful taste and not overly greasy but about right. Good portion of beef. Enjoyed it.  Four stars.

Beef stew wonton soup (4.75) . Very good and tasty. Large portion. Soup had a wonderful taste to it as did the added meat and noodles including the wonton. Four stars.

Restaurant was crowded (weekday 1:30 PM)  At one point, we had to share our table, but that was all right. 

Service was average. 

Prices are EXCEPTIONALLY low. Large portions, good food and low prices. Five stars for price/value.

Overall would give it a four star. 

Will be in town until October. Will be sure to return there.

excerpts: and I have it over rice or wonton noodles.
wonton.author: Rosie W.
wonton.review:
I call this Chinese soul food. 

I used to come here alot when I was younger. There's been so many owners since then but the quality of the food remains good. It's a little run down, it can be dirty (just wash the utensils in the hot tea) and the waitresses can be a bit rude, but I swear the food is good! I love their meats - roasted duck is my favorite and I have it over rice or wonton noodles. If you feel like having more than one type of meat, you can can order it that way too - like roasted duck and soy sauce chicken over rice. They're not shady with the portions and it just delicious. Easy, quick, delicious meal.

Please try not to get grossed out with how run down/dirty it is! Give it a chance if you haven't been.

excerpts: I got a Roast duck wonton noodle soup $5 or so.
I got it with large rice noodles.
Some pieces of the duck were good, but others mostly bones & fat.
Wontons were small, some bok choy with the soup.
wonton.author: Ann L.
wonton.review:
Cash Only.  We went to Kam Po Kitchen for dinner Fri 11/26/10.  It's a hole-in-the-wall place in SF Chinatown on Powell St.

We were heading elsewhere, but have always to try this place & since it was in front of us we went in.

Food is cheap, but not all that great.

I got a Roast duck wonton noodle soup $5 or so.  I got it with large rice noodles.  Some pieces of the duck were good, but others mostly bones & fat.  Wontons were small, some bok choy with the soup.  Just ok.

B. got beef stew noodle soup about $5 - one piece of beef stew was tender, other pieces he said wasn't very tender.  He got egg noodle & like that ok.

B. ordered chicken feet about $5 - I thought they were pretty bad.  Not very tender, not enough flavor.  Skip it.

Someone ordered a plate of 1/2 roast chicken meat & 1/2 bbq pork over rice w/ side of veggies.  That looked good.

Another table tried to get chow fun - waitress said they ran out of chow fun!  That's strange.  They picked chow mein instead.

There's 1 unisex bathroom - didn't use it.

Before tip was $15.20.  Cash Only.

excerpts: We ordered a Beef Stew Flat Noodle Soup (Ngau Lam Tong Ho), a Wonton Noodle Soup, and a plate of Cha Siu.
The Cha Siu was probably the best part of the meal.
It was pretty lean, tender, and juicy.
I thought it was seasoned pretty well with salt and savory spices, but it could have been sweeter.
wonton.author: Nei N.
wonton.review:
After seeing this place packed full of people with delicious looking food, my friend and I spontaneously decided to eat lunch here. The portions were huge, and the food was cheap, but the food wasn't the best. 

We ordered a Beef Stew Flat Noodle Soup (Ngau Lam Tong Ho), a Wonton Noodle Soup, and a plate of Cha Siu. The Cha Siu was probably the best part of the meal. It was pretty lean, tender, and juicy. I thought it was seasoned pretty well with salt and savory spices, but it could have been sweeter. It didn't have that glistening glaze on the outside which was kind of a let down. 

From the outside windows, the noodles soups looked pretty good. It was the main reason why we got them. I could tell that the wontons were all shrimp just by peering through the glass. Despite the really slow service, I was still really excited to dig into my bowl when it arrived. When I took my first bite, my excitement quickly dwindled as the broth and noodles were so bland. The wontons really were all shrimp which is what you'd find in more desirable upscale wontons, but they also lacked any kind of seasoning. My friend's broth was similarly bland, and her beef was tough and flavorless. It was pretty disappointing all around. Maybe the roast duck is better? I guess on the plus side, it's cheap.

excerpts: Bomb roast duck wonton noodle soup.
Bowl was loaded and flavor was excellent.
Noodles were thin and chewy.
I'll be Back!
wonton.author: Jack N.
wonton.review: Bomb roast duck wonton noodle soup. Bowl was loaded and flavor was excellent. Noodles were thin and chewy. "I'll be Back!"

excerpts: We also split the shrimp wonton soup, but it was so much food that we had leftovers.
wonton.author: Michele P.
wonton.review:
Cheap and DELICIOUS--people do not come here for ambience or exceptional service.

Regardless of the latter, Kam Po deserves four stars for the nommy food alone. The bf and I each got the roast duck (crispy skin + juicy meat + tasty sauce = orgasms in my mouth), which comes with a hearty portion of rice and veggies. We also split the shrimp wonton soup, but it was so much food that we had leftovers.

A meal for two and a snack for later, for only $13.50??? We'll definitely be back! I'll try the BBQ pork next time, though it might be hard to pass up that scrumptious duck--but for ~$5 per meal, I'll probably end up just ordering and chowing down on both. :)

excerpts: The roast duck in wonton noodle soup is also one of my favorite hangover cures.
wonton.author: Jon L.
wonton.review:
If you're looking for the best roast meats in Chinatown, hands-down it's probably found at Kam Po Kitchen. In fact, rumor has it that they provide the roast meats for several other eateries around. 

I believe it's almost 4 years to the day that I stumbled upon Kam Po. I had just moved to the city and got lost in the labyrinth that is Chinatown at night but it was a most fortuitous detour since I found my go-to Chinese roast house. 

First off the roast duck is just such a guilty pleasure. Wonderfully fatty and tasty with the most perfectly crispy and succulent skin. Order it over rice and you can easily split it into 2 meals. The roast duck in wonton noodle soup is also one of my favorite hangover cures. The plump wontons and the warm soup work in tandem with the duck to get me out of my funk. 

If you've never seen a whole roasted pig come out of the roaster then you need to get here. It truly is a sight to behold when they bring the whole perfectly roasted hog out and hang it on display for all to see. What's impressive is they actually go through more than a pig a day. But wait till you bite into it. The crispy skin is perfection - the kind of thing that makes Anthony Bourdain salivate on camera. 

I've had other dishes here ranging from salted fish fried rice to dry fried beef chowfun and they are all decent but the real stars at Kam Po are without a doubt their roast meats. Considering that meals here are so inexpensive (most average around the $5 mark) though, it's hard to order something wrong.

The service is fast and earnest here especially the lady with the short cropped hair. She is a star here and runs a very tight ship. She negates the attitude from the grumpy butcher.  Don't come here for the ambiance. It's a dive. Order take out if you're afraid of the place but trust me you won't regret it. The food at Kam Po is truly yummy.

excerpts: We ordered beef chow fun, wonton soup with roast pork, and rice plate 1/2 duck 1/2 pork, it was all very good and CHEAP!
wonton.author: Shawn G.
wonton.review:
Last night in SF we went here for dinner. Seated quickly, waitress was a little abrupt and was sure to tell us cash only before taking our order. The place was full and there was only the one extremely busy waitress. Also it seemed strange they did not have ice. 

We ordered beef chow fun, wonton soup with roast pork, and rice plate 1/2 duck 1/2 pork, it was all very good and CHEAP!

excerpts: We ordered Beef Intestines, Beef Tripe, Chinese Broccoli, and several bowls of Wonton Noodle Soup, and Duck Noodle Soup.
All of the portions were insane, everything is between $4-$7 and it's SO MUCH FOOD.
wonton.author: Corey P.
wonton.review:
Let's get to the point: this place gives you RIDICULOUSLY LARGE DELICIOUS PORTIONS for CHEAP. 

We ordered Beef Intestines, Beef Tripe, Chinese Broccoli, and several bowls of Wonton Noodle Soup, and Duck Noodle Soup. All of the portions were insane, everything is between $4-$7 and it's SO MUCH FOOD. More importantly, it was delicious, savory, and filling.

This place was actually very busy for a hole-in-the-wall place. My BIGGEST COMPLAINT is that the restaurant is SUPER SMALL and PRETTY DIRTY. The floors were sticky and there was crumbs and things of that nature everywhere.

Service is fast, friendly (particularly if you can speak Chinese), and it was an overall enjoyable experience if you exclude how cramped and untidy it was. If you're visiting San Francisco and you're hungry, swing by here with some friends, share the food family style, and be satisfied out of your mind.

excerpts: For $4.95 I got a pretty good bowl of roast duck and wonton noodle soup.
Also, keep in mind that this is a Chinese BBQ place where the "star attraction" is the roast duck.
Therefore don't expect a super-clean place.
wonton.author: H K.
wonton.review:
I returned here for lunch last week due to some field work in the area.  The menu now still shows a lot of Chinese BBQ rice or noodle soup dishes for under $5 before tax and tip.  For $4.95 I got a pretty good bowl of roast duck and wonton noodle soup.

The waitress who served me was quite nice, a plus for a restaurant like this.  I recall it wasn't as busy as previous times I came for lunch (don't recall if it was because it was a later hour like after 1pm).  That was good for me because in the past during very busy hours the service can become very disorganized (especially when there's also a line of people ordering Chinese BBQ for takeout).

Also, keep in mind that this is a Chinese BBQ place where the "star attraction" is the roast duck.  Therefore don't expect a super-clean place.

excerpts: My favorite go to choice is the Roasted Duck with Lo Mien OR Wonton Soup.
Regardless, they're both delicious and filling.
wonton.author: Joyce M.
wonton.review:
CHEAP. DELICIOUS. FILLING. CHEAP

What more can you ask for if you can get a decent meal for just about $6! My favorite go to choice is the Roasted Duck with Lo Mien OR Wonton Soup. Regardless, they're both delicious and filling. These go around $5.

The place is packed during lunch and dinner time so be sure to get there early to snag a spot. It's so popular that they always seat small parties on the same table and just hustle and bustle the flow to get customers full and going.

excerpts: The duck wonton soup is great and also comes with chow win noodles in it, so no need to order another noodle dish.
wonton.author: David W.
wonton.review:
Great little spot if you want classic Chinese in China town!  The plates are big!  I recommend the garlic broccoli.  

The duck wonton soup is great and also comes with chow win noodles in it, so no need to order another noodle dish.

Also, they only accept cash!

excerpts: To me this is as comforting as it gets; wonton noodle soup, duck noodle soup, you name it, you got it!
wonton.author: Ann Hui Y.
wonton.review:
To me this is as comforting as it gets; wonton noodle soup, duck noodle soup, you name it, you got it! To be truly honest, the roast duck is right on, it's juicy and fragrant. Good place for a quick lunch and with the crazy hilltop winds, you're served with a cup of hot Chinese tea, and i mean HOT! 

Maybe the place doesn't look much, but it has that hong kong old coffee house vibes, somewhere to get a great and easy bite without having to put on a suit. Parking might be a little bit of a pain, but if you want great food, then you'll probably just have to find one to stop by.

excerpts: Noodles, rice, wonton soup, congee/jook, and some stir fry dishes.
Come here for their BBQ though... innards, duck, roast pig, BBQ pork, etc.
Oh yeah...the duck here is LEAN.
wonton.author: Fannie S.
wonton.review:
Crazy cheap. Crazy good. Crazy busy!

Food = plentiful, savory, delicious, and just filling!  Presentation = good.  Noodles, rice, wonton soup, congee/jook, and some stir fry dishes.  Come here for their BBQ though... innards, duck, roast pig, BBQ pork, etc.  Oh yeah...the duck here is LEAN.  No, not fat-free, lardbutt, I said LEAN (as in not all fat!)

Service = hustle, bustle but super friendly!

Decor = throwback to 1980's NY Chinatown joints.  

Seating = simple tables and chairs.  If it's busy, expect to sit with a bunch of unknown people.  They'll keep the tabs SEPARATE.  

Prices = cheap! Cash only, yo!

Overall, we'll be back...whether it's take out for dinner fix or quickie lunch fix.

Quasi-Chinese Lesson of the Day: 
Kam Po...is the same phrase as the words Kung Pao (in Chinese characters)...which is derived from  gng bo , literally, palace guardian.

excerpts: Tried this place because I passed by and the smell of wonton noodle soup drew me in.
That's how my bf and I found our beloved wonton place in HK
We got the huge chicken leg as a side and duck wonton noodle soup.
The chicken leg had good flavor on the skin- soy sauce-y but the insides were a bit too dry.
THe wonton noodle soup base was good and light.
THe wontons were pretty good-had a lot of shrimp and yellow chives.
However the noodles were not so good.
Tasted wheaty and a bit dry.
But haven't tried any other bbq meat/wonton place in SF
so I'm not sure how this is compared to them.
It's decent I guess.. but nothing compared to the ones I've had in HK or NY's Big Wong.
wonton.author: Elizabeth N.
wonton.review:
Tried this place because I passed by and the smell of wonton noodle soup drew me in. That's how my bf and I found our beloved wonton place in HK so we thought we had found the ONE in SF. 

However, this place was a bit disappointing. The staff of two middle-aged women were welcoming and super nice. We got the huge chicken leg as a side and duck wonton noodle soup. The chicken leg had good flavor on the skin- soy sauce-y but the insides were a bit too dry. THe wonton noodle soup base was good and light. THe wontons were pretty good-had a lot of shrimp and yellow chives. However the noodles were not so good. Tasted wheaty and a bit dry. Did not have any elasticity. 

But haven't tried any other bbq meat/wonton place in SF so I'm not sure how this is compared to them. It's decent I guess.. but nothing compared to the ones I've had in HK or NY's Big Wong.

excerpts: Very good Wonton, meaty morsels wrapped in just the right thickness of Wonton skin.
Atmosphere for dining is undesirable, prefer to order to go.
The food is actually deserving of 4.5 star rating.
wonton.author: Paul L.
wonton.review: The best roast duck and roast pork in Chinatown. The Chow fun and HK style pan fried noodles (chow mein) are top notch too. Very good Wonton, meaty morsels wrapped in just the right thickness of Wonton skin. Atmosphere for dining is undesirable, prefer to order to go. The food is actually deserving of 4.5 star rating.

excerpts: There was bbq pork, steamed chicken, wonton soup, fried rice ...
wonton.author: Jesse A.
wonton.review:
Loved the shared tables at this place -- we shared with two old Chinese ladies and tried to order what they did. But they ordered so much food, we couldn't keep up! There was bbq pork, steamed chicken, wonton soup, fried rice ... it just went on and on. 

Kam Po was very cheap, though other reviewers are right about the sticky tables and cramped conditions. Also, it's pretty tricky to figure out what to order (and you can go really wrong that way), so it's best to read more detailed Yelp reviews before arriving (which we hadn't).

Kam Po was lively and fast, but I didn't think the food was actually that spectacular. It certainly has a dedicated local following, so they must be doing something right.

excerpts: In particular the roast duck wonton noodle soup is my favorite in the city.
wonton.author: David H.
wonton.review:
There are two things for certain when coming to Kam Po: 1) you'll probably be eating at a greasy-looking table wiped down by a towel about 3 months past its prime; 2) the food will be ridiculously good. So if you can overlook #1 (when did we all become such sissies in SF?), then you're in for a treat.

Kam Po is definitely my go-to spot when I'm hankering for roast duck, roast pork, bbq pork, or any other culinary treat that can be hooked and dangled in front of a window. In particular the roast duck wonton noodle soup is my favorite in the city. The wontons are super flavorful, perfect ration of meat to wrapper without that weird gummy consistency, and don't make me feel like I'm eating dumpling bought from Costco; and they are definitely not at all skimpy on the roast duck portion which is more than generous.

Kam Po is one of those places that actually feels and looks like what one would imagine to be an authentic Chinatown restaurant.

Looking forward to my next bowl of soup!

excerpts: However, the wonton skin was not as silky smooth as I normally prefer.
wonton.author: Tina W.
wonton.review: If you're looking for a cheap chinese meal, this is the place to go. The portions are also quite big considering the amount you pay.  The roast pork was very fatty and juicy. However, the wonton skin was not as silky smooth as I normally prefer.

excerpts: the soup noodles are top notch - we had bbq pork spareribs with noodles, and crispy roast pork with wonton mein.
both items were under $5 (each was $6 including tip).
wonton.author: Jason J.
wonton.review:
another 5 star review for food only.  

chinese people get scared away by this place - so this is a warning to all non chinese people - this is a hole in the wall.  its been this way for years, and the food is excellent.  ignore the fact that it looks "gross" (aka normal chinatown).

the service is fast, done by one gal who is pretty damn good at her job.

the soup noodles are top notch - we had bbq pork spareribs with noodles, and crispy roast pork with wonton mein.  both items were under $5 (each was $6 including tip).

excerpts: I've only had the roast pork (siu yuk) wonton noodle soup.
It's a pretty filling bowl with several wontons and a lot of roast pork.
It's a pretty good deal because I paid about $8 after tip.
There's actually quite a huge selection of different dishes... vegetables, rice, meats... pretty much all the standard cantonese foods.
The best part about the restaurant is sitting inside facing the counter, and watching everyone at work.
There's usually one waitress around who always has a smile on her face.
There's another tough looking woman, whose duties revolve around managing the money, the chopping block, and serving customers.
She seems like a real strict boss type, but after a while of watching her at work, you'll soon come to see that she's just a really hard-working person who means well.
Finally, there's butcher who is never without his cleaver.
He might be handling money when he's the only guy behind the counter, but don't misunderstand.
He's here to take care of all the meat, from the roast ducks behind the window to the huge slab of siu yuk hanging as the centerpiece of the room.
Everything about him from his physical appearance, demeanor, and his skill with the cleaver indicates that he is the embodiment of the original chinese deli butcher.
Come if you're interested in some nice chinese food with some real characters to observe while you eat.
wonton.author: Andrew S.
wonton.review: I've only had the roast pork (siu yuk) wonton noodle soup. It's a pretty filling bowl with several wontons and a lot of roast pork. It's a pretty good deal because I paid about $8 after tip. There's actually quite a huge selection of different dishes... vegetables, rice, meats... pretty much all the standard cantonese foods. There's another tough looking woman, whose duties revolve around managing the money, the chopping block, and serving customers. He's here to take care of all the meat, from the roast ducks behind the window to the huge slab of siu yuk hanging as the centerpiece of the room. Everything about him from his physical appearance, demeanor, and his skill with the cleaver indicates that he is the embodiment of the original chinese deli butcher.
