excerpts: There are the tradition wonton noodles with ur choosing of a meat .
Apointer if u get bbq items on soup dish always ask for it on dish, its a much better cut.
This place is really inexpensive and yes its cash only and they close around 7pm.
wonton.author: Jorm K.
wonton.review:
3 n half stars

Hmm this place is your typically hole in the wall of chinatown. So the place is a little greasy and grimey. The Chinese bbq is above par roast pig bbq pork and duck. For those who are adventurist there are pig intestines , bbq chicken livers, and pork stomach stew in soy sauce. There are the tradition wonton noodles with ur choosing of a meat . Apointer if u get bbq items on soup dish always ask for it on dish, its a much better cut. This place is really inexpensive and yes its cash only and they close around 7pm.

excerpts: Dirty little place, but they can make jook and wonton soup any way you want it, and their roast duck is sumptuous.
Very affordable prices.
Don't take skittish people here, though.
I haven't been back in a while, but this is the kind of place that stays precisely the same for years and years.
wonton.author: Josh K.
wonton.review: Dirty little place, but they can make jook and wonton soup any way you want it, and their roast duck is sumptuous. Very affordable prices. Don't take skittish people here, though. I haven't been back in a while, but this is the kind of place that stays precisely the same for years and years.

excerpts: Whether it's wonton and roast pork noodle soup or a soy sauce chicken rice dish, you get gigantic portions (that to a normal person is two servings, but I tend to eat a lot).
That's not all as well,
before you get your entree you get a bowl of delicious homemade soup.
wonton.author: Jon W.
wonton.review:
I'm amazed that I haven't reviewed this place until now, because, really, when it comes to affordable Chinese restaurants you can't get better than big portions + good food + bare basement prices. Whether it's wonton and roast pork noodle soup or a soy sauce chicken rice dish, you get gigantic portions (that to a normal person is two servings, but I tend to eat a lot). That's not all as well, before you get your entree you get a bowl of delicious homemade soup. All that for less than $6 (I wish I could get anything for less than $6 now that I live in DC)

Okay, so the place may not be the most sanitary of places. The tables are pretty cramped and during busy times you'll have to share. And yes, it's cash only (but that's pretty much anywhere in Chinatown anyways). But really, all that is worth it for the lipsmaking goodness coming your way at Kam Po. I'm definitely looking forward to coming back to San Francisco again and eating another delicious meal here.

excerpts: I love the wonton with noodles for $2.55.
23 years ago, it was $2.30, so their prices are super reasonable.
A bowl of JUST wonton is like eating a bowl of dim sum.
Lots of shrimp in the wonton.
You got to try their wonton
it's truely amazing, like dim sum.
It's the cheapest and best wonton, I've had...
"Two
Kinds o BBQ" is $5.50 which is a lot of meat.
wonton.author: Sunny O.
wonton.review:
They got 88 out 100 in their health inspection.  I've never got sick from eating this place.  They sell a lot so, there's never any stale food.  All local Chinese customers eat here, not like NanKing where there's only "white" folks (get it?).  

I love the wonton with noodles for $2.55.  23 years ago, it was $2.30, so their prices are super reasonable.  
A bowl of JUST wonton is like eating a bowl of dim sum.  Lots of shrimp in the wonton.   You got to try their wonton it's truely amazing, like dim sum.  It's the cheapest and best wonton, I've had..."Two Kinds o BBQ" is $5.50 which is a lot of meat.  Feel free to share it.

It's not fair to review a restaurant if you havent' eaten their food.  I've been eating in Chinatown for over 30 years and this is a secret hold in the wall.   Yes, the tables are old, but they are clean.  Once in a while the floors are sticky, but they do wash it every night.  Most good, cheap places like this one is CASH ONLY

excerpts: my mom reminds me these days "only $3 for a bowl of noodle with EIGHT wonton!
wonton.author: Katie K.
wonton.review:
every time I hear the term "dirty hole in the wall", I think of Kam Po Kitchen immediately. the place would probably not pass well with the health rating but what I don't see, I don't care. if you want a quick good bite with the best deal in Chinatown....here it is. no frills and not the best Chinese place to give off any great impressions to first timers.

I've been a regular here since I was a kid growing up in the area (in fact, my family first moved into an apt. upstairs when we first immigrated to the States). my mom reminds me these days "only $3 for a bowl of noodle with EIGHT wonton!" that is a bargain you can't find elsewhere.

* if getting the soup noodles to go, ask for the soup in a seperate container so you don't end up with soggy noodles.

excerpts: Ordered the beef chow fun, wonton soup with like 12 pieces of wonton and bbq pork rice plate.
The bill was $10.35.
What other places can beat that!
The place is small and can be dirty, just like any AUTHENTIC, typical chinese restaurant is.
But if you're use to little hole in the wall type of chinese restaurant and finding good food is the primary reason, then you gotta give this place a try.
wonton.author: Heidi F.
wonton.review: the cheapest chinese restaurant in SF!!!  Ordered the beef chow fun, wonton soup with like 12 pieces of wonton and bbq pork rice plate.  The bill was $10.35.  What other places can beat that!  The place is small and can be dirty, just like any AUTHENTIC, typical chinese restaurant is.  But if you're use to little hole in the wall type of chinese restaurant and finding good food is the primary reason, then you gotta give this place a try.

excerpts: I like it in the wonton soup or the China green chow-mien or
even just plain by itself.
wonton.author: will s.
wonton.review:
The first time I came to Kam Po h.k.k. (I pretend it stands for Hong Kong Kapaow) I pushed aside the fork in favor of chopsticks which happen to be a far superior eating utensil. I'm not sure if chopsticks are usual fare for non-Chinese people eating in Chinatown, then again I'm not sure if many non-Chinese people eat in Chinatown or H.K.K. for that matter but either way the lady that serves food here seemed quite amused. Since then she has been very friendly, gives me free tea, and always makes it a point to give me chopsticks.

Anyway, the food here is the best, the best Chinese food ever in fact. Try anything that contains the BBQ Pork. I like it in the wonton soup or the China green chow-mien or even just plain by itself. The soy sauce chicken is also delicious as is pretty much anything on the menu. And you know it's fresh because they pull it straight out of the window. Oh and make sure you look at the menu you can hold in your hand rather then the menu on the window because it has more food choices on it.

If I could give a bonus star for every inch of hair that's growing out of the face mole of the meat-chopper guy, I would.

excerpts: (They also serve a hefty shrimp dumpling and roast duck noodle soup here for a little over $6!
Screw Katana-ya.)
dumpling.author: Linus W.
dumpling.review: Affordable solid little no-frills chinese place specializing in roast and bbq meats it seems. Had a non-standard "hainan chicken" dish here ($6), along w/ some dou miao ($6.50) to balance out the meal. The chicken dish while tasty was closer to the canto "Bái qie ji", or poached chicken w/ a ginger-scallion-garlic oil sauce, on top of a bed of pickled vegetables. AFAIK, that is not the type of sauce one uses for hainanese chicken. The rice also was lighter flavored and colored; I'm told really good hainan chicken rice should have a nice yellow hue and be more strongly flavored of chicken. Still, the food is a great deal here; I wanna come back and try some of their jook. (They also serve a hefty shrimp dumpling and roast duck noodle soup here for a little over $6! Screw Katana-ya.)

excerpts: The wontons are super flavorful, perfect ration of meat to wrapper without that weird gummy consistency, and don't make me feel like I'm eating dumpling bought from Costco; and they are definitely not at all skimpy on the roast duck portion which is more than generous.
dumpling.author: David H.
dumpling.review:
There are two things for certain when coming to Kam Po: 1) you'll probably be eating at a greasy-looking table wiped down by a towel about 3 months past its prime; 2) the food will be ridiculously good. So if you can overlook #1 (when did we all become such sissies in SF?), then you're in for a treat.

Kam Po is definitely my go-to spot when I'm hankering for roast duck, roast pork, bbq pork, or any other culinary treat that can be hooked and dangled in front of a window. In particular the roast duck wonton noodle soup is my favorite in the city. The wontons are super flavorful, perfect ration of meat to wrapper without that weird gummy consistency, and don't make me feel like I'm eating dumpling bought from Costco; and they are definitely not at all skimpy on the roast duck portion which is more than generous.

Kam Po is one of those places that actually feels and looks like what one would imagine to be an authentic Chinatown restaurant.

Looking forward to my next bowl of soup!

excerpts: I got the roast duck rice noodles ($6.25).
The soup was amazing (the magic of MSG, i think LOL this assumption is not verified
but it tasted like it).
I was stuffed afterward.
Honestly i was so happy the entire time i was eating.
roast duck rice noodles.author: Jen K.
roast duck rice noodles.review:
honestly yall idk why people be trippin over service quality. the nonchalance is kinda just a part of the Chinese food culture and adds to the authenticity. Besides the service was fine when i went. The workers were eating when we came in to sit, but server still came to serve us and took our order and etc. 

Anyway, I LOVE THIS PLACE. I was raised in Hong Kong and this place totally brings back memories. If you want authentic taste, this is it. If i had to show someone what i usually eat in hk, id take them to this place. Andddd this is what they call "best value". you get a good amount of food for the price you pay, and its so tastyyy! Total GOOD DEAL.

I got the roast duck rice noodles ($6.25). The soup was amazing (the magic of MSG, i think LOL this assumption is not verified but it tasted like it). I was stuffed afterward. Honestly i was so happy the entire time i was eating. I WOULD DEFINITELY COME BACK.

and remember, CASH ONLY.

excerpts: Kam Po Kitchen offers sit-down meal service or a take-out line for those who wish to bring home roast duck, soy sauce chicken or any meat of the sort.
Roast duck over rice, duck wonton soup and prawn with egg chow fun are all good choices.
Everything is also inexpensive.
Unlike many of the butcher shops in Chinatown, Kam Po does not skimp out on the meat.
soy sauce chicken.author: Philip M.
soy sauce chicken.review:
everything is so darn good here.

Kam Po Kitchen doesn't serve up Michelin-standard cooking, but it serves up big hearty portions of delicious Hong Kong style dishes. There are a lot of tables within the restaurant but all the tables are very close to each other. Be prepared to share some personal space! Kam Po Kitchen offers sit-down meal service or a take-out line for those who wish to bring home roast duck, soy sauce chicken or any meat of the sort. 

I have tried a number of the dishes offered here. Roast duck over rice, duck wonton soup and prawn with egg chow fun are all good choices. Everything is also inexpensive. Unlike many of the butcher shops in Chinatown, Kam Po does not skimp out on the meat. I have tried the prawn with egg chow fun dish throughout many Chinese restaurants in Chinatown, and the one here is hands down the best. 

Many of the staff members here don't speak English. Two of the female staff speaks English and provides good service though. The only thing that irks me is that the dining tables are always so greasy or oily from a lack of quality deep cleaning. This is a very popular lunch spot for locals in Chinatown. Kam Po is great for your stomach and easy on your wallet and it's definitely one of my favorite lunch spots in Chinatown! CASH ONLY!

excerpts: But we ordered roast duck, roast pork, bbq pork, pork intestines, chicken feet, &soy sauce chicken.
When we got home tonight, we had a feast!
soy sauce chicken.author: Lihz P.
soy sauce chicken.review:
Fairly cheap. Big portions. Quick service! Always packed! So not really great for big groups unless you're willing to wait..

Came in today with my family (party of 10) around 2:30pm and there were no tables open so we waited a good 20-25 minutes before a table opened up. The staff was very nice and quick to let us know it'll be a while until we were seated which was no problem because only half of us were there first. 
--Minus 1 star for all the people who came in after us and seated themselves at random tables instead of waiting to be seated.--
By the time the rest of the party was there it only took us about 5 more minutes until we were seated.

Onto the food... We decided to do family style dinner, so we ordered wonton soup, seafood tofu soup, salted fish fried rice, pan fried house noodles, beef chow fun, roasted pork belly, Garlic Chinese broccoli, garlic water spinach and fish with sweet corn over rice, all to share amongst each other. Everything was really good and our tummies were satisfied! The dish that stood out the most to me was the fish w sweet corn! It sounded weird at first, but don't knock it til you try it!

Obviously, since they sell fresh af Chinese bbq in store as well, we had to buy some to bring home for family dinner! Sadly they didn't have oxtail.. But we ordered roast duck, roast pork, bbq pork, pork intestines, chicken feet, &soy sauce chicken. When we got home tonight, we had a feast! Ate all that with side of baguettes & soy sauce, Vietnamese style! 

This is always my family's go to lunch spot when we're in Chinatown SF. We'll be back soon!

excerpts: I ordered the Soy Sauce Chicken with Rice.
My boyfriend ordered BBQ Pork with Rice.
And we shared a Roasted Pork with Wanton Noodle Soup.
The portions were pretty decent and the price was right...only $19 for those three items.
Service was alright.
Cleanliness was probably not of the highest order.
This seemed like a pretty authentic style of cooking.
Out of all the items ordered, I liked the BBQ Pork the best -- I'd give that a 4/5 and would return for that.
I loved the way it was seasoned.
Soy Sauce Chicken was pretty good -- 3.5/5.
Neither one of us was super stoked about the soup.
It was nice to have some warm soup on a cold day.
And it wasn't bad.
But it wasn't a favorite either.
We both liked the BBQ pork the best.
I'd give the overall experience a 3.5 out of 5.
soy sauce chicken.author: Renee F.
soy sauce chicken.review: Good stuff! I ordered the Soy Sauce Chicken with Rice. My boyfriend ordered BBQ Pork with Rice. And we shared a Roasted Pork with Wanton Noodle Soup. The portions were pretty decent and the price was right...only $19 for those three items. Service was alright. Cleanliness was probably not of the highest order. This seemed like a pretty authentic style of cooking. Out of all the items ordered, I liked the BBQ Pork the best -- I'd give that a 4/5 and would return for that. I loved the way it was seasoned. Soy Sauce Chicken was pretty good -- 3.5/5. Neither one of us was super stoked about the soup. It was nice to have some warm soup on a cold day. And it wasn't bad. But it wasn't a favorite either. We both liked the BBQ pork the best. I'd give the overall experience a 3.5 out of 5.

excerpts: The Soy Sauce Chicken, Roast Pork and Roast Duck - lean and delicious!
soy sauce chicken.author: Bennett W.
soy sauce chicken.review:
Black Pepper Beef & Rice is delicious. The rice plate serving portion seemed very generous so it's definitely a nice lunch meal. Service is good and some of the staff members here are friendly. There is also a fair amount of seating available if you plan on eating here.

Overall:
- good food
- good prices
- good service
- positive first experience

I'm definitely making my way back for lunch when I am nearby.

*The Soy Sauce Chicken, Roast Pork and Roast Duck - lean and delicious!

excerpts: We had the bbq duck wonton egg noodle soup, soy sauce chicken fun noodle soup, Chinese broccoli, two meat rice platter.
All were delicious.
Easy 5 stars if it weren't for the rude gesture of leaving a tip when we haven't yet left....
soy sauce chicken.author: Jo J.
soy sauce chicken.review: Yummmmy. We had the bbq duck wonton egg noodle soup, soy sauce chicken fun noodle soup, Chinese broccoli, two meat rice platter. All were delicious. Easy 5 stars if it weren't for the rude gesture of leaving a tip when we haven't yet left....

excerpts: If you feel like having more than one type of meat, you can can order it that way too - like roasted duck and soy sauce chicken over rice.
They're not shady with the portions and it just delicious.
soy sauce chicken.author: Rosie W.
soy sauce chicken.review:
I call this Chinese soul food. 

I used to come here alot when I was younger. There's been so many owners since then but the quality of the food remains good. It's a little run down, it can be dirty (just wash the utensils in the hot tea) and the waitresses can be a bit rude, but I swear the food is good! I love their meats - roasted duck is my favorite and I have it over rice or wonton noodles. If you feel like having more than one type of meat, you can can order it that way too - like roasted duck and soy sauce chicken over rice. They're not shady with the portions and it just delicious. Easy, quick, delicious meal.

Please try not to get grossed out with how run down/dirty it is! Give it a chance if you haven't been.

excerpts: We decided to sample a little bit of everything and ordered two-item plates of BBQ pork, cold-boiled chicken, roasted pork, and soy sauce chicken over rice.
While the cleanliness is a bit suspect, all of their meats are top quality for a Chinese restaurant.
Everything was very meaty and generally devoid of excessive fat, and the portions were huge.
If we knew that we wouldn't have to walk around with it for the rest of the day, we probably would have taken the leftovers home.
soy sauce chicken.author: Joe M.
soy sauce chicken.review:
San Francisco has some really great Chinese "chop" houses serving up heaping dishes of BBQ duck, BBQ and roasted pork, and several varieties of chicken over rice, but there is only one the I've been coming to consistently with my dad over the years.  Taking a break from our urban exploring, my buddy and I decided to drop in for some solid Chinese food to fill our empty bellies.

We decided to sample a little bit of everything and ordered two-item plates of BBQ pork, cold-boiled chicken, roasted pork, and soy sauce chicken over rice.  While the cleanliness is a bit suspect, all of their meats are top quality for a Chinese restaurant.  Everything was very meaty and generally devoid of excessive fat, and the portions were huge.  If we knew that we wouldn't have to walk around with it for the rest of the day, we probably would have taken the leftovers home.  In fact, there was so much food that we probably could have just shared a single plate between the two of us.

Whenever I'm in North Beach, I'm pretty much drawn toward Kam Po for lunch.  It's a fantastic bargain and I would normally be able to make two meals out of the one, saving a lot of time and money while enjoying great food.  For the price of a fast food meal, I can get some of the best, authentic, Hong Kong-style BBQ short of actually going to Hong Kong!

Food: 9/10

Service: 6/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 6/10

excerpts: We called to order soy sauce chicken over rice and a beef chow fun to go on our way home
and they were ready when we got there less than 10 minutes later...
here's the topper, $8.90!
2 orders including tax - $8.90!
Crazy.
soy sauce chicken.author: Gloria H.
soy sauce chicken.review:
Still a fan.  Last meal there was ok - soup noodle was lacking a little flavor but you still can't beat the price, portion and speed.  

For the first time, we ordered stuff to go.  We called to order soy sauce chicken over rice and a beef chow fun to go on our way home and they were ready when we got there less than 10 minutes later...here's the topper, $8.90!  2 orders including tax - $8.90!  Crazy.  It was damn good too. 

We ordered to go again.  This time, roast duck over rice and bitter melon and beef pan fried noodles - $9.80!  Still under $10!  

Fast, cheap, large portion...this is the place.

excerpts: Prices were very reasonable; our party of three ordered a roast pork and duck rice, a soy sauce chicken rice, beef chow fun, and a seafood tofu clay pot, and that came out to be around 25 dollars (plus a lot of leftovers enough for a second meal)!
The roast pork was crispy on the outside, and both the duck meat and chicken were tender and juicy.
Since being a legit Chinese restaurant, service wasn't the best, but we got our food in a timely manner (and the waitress seemed overwhelmed manning the whole store by herself).
Would come back again if I go back to SF!
soy sauce chicken.author: Raymond C.
soy sauce chicken.review: Came here since I was in SF and wanted some legit Canto food. Prices were very reasonable; our party of three ordered a roast pork and duck rice, a soy sauce chicken rice, beef chow fun, and a seafood tofu clay pot, and that came out to be around 25 dollars (plus a lot of leftovers enough for a second meal)! The roast pork was crispy on the outside, and both the duck meat and chicken were tender and juicy. Since being a legit Chinese restaurant, service wasn't the best, but we got our food in a timely manner (and the waitress seemed overwhelmed manning the whole store by herself). Would come back again if I go back to SF!

excerpts: About two months ago about one hour from closing, I bought a $6 soy sauce chicken (this is the small size type, cheaper).
Got home, open the box, right away I could smell the spoiled odor.
Got back to my car, drove back there, looked for parking again, knocked on the door (they closed already)
they did not examine the content of my returned box but gave me my refund!
From my experience,  the person who chopped up the chicken (I think he is the owner?) should know that it was spoiled because as he chopped it up, he should smelled the bad odor.
Yesterday, I bought another $6 chicken during lunch time (should be pretty fresh at this time of day).
Went home and found chicken meat to be rubbery and skin so chewy that I cannot break any skin in the box.
Believe me, I have good teeth.
I was eating that chicken with a friend (who specifically wanted soy sauce chicken for dinner) at home and it was extremely embarrassing.
And frustrated again because the same guy who chopped up the meat should know it was very chewy (from the feel of the knife gets into the chicken).
I did not go back to ask for a refund.
I think I want to calm down for a few months to ease my blood pressure then see...
My family has been in the restaurant business in the East Bay for twenty years.
One of the restaurants we had owned, was a Chinese BBQ restaurant like Kam Po!
So I had worked in a BBQ restaurant before.
For irresponsible business ethics, one star.
soy sauce chicken.author: Adrian A.
soy sauce chicken.review:
I have been buying meat (hanged on the rack) from this place a few times a year for a couple of years. Quality is ok. I like it mainly because it is easier to find parking on this part of Chinatown. When I buy I usually bring the exact amount, so that I don't get any change back from the person who chops up the meat -  the change money is always mixed with grease.
About two months ago about one hour from closing, I bought a $6 soy sauce chicken (this is the small size type, cheaper). Got home, open the box, right away I could smell the spoiled odor. Got back to my car, drove back there, looked for parking again, knocked on the door (they closed already) they did not examine the content of my returned box but gave me my refund! From my experience,  the person who chopped up the chicken (I think he is the owner?) should know that it was spoiled because as he chopped it up, he should smelled the bad odor.
Yesterday, I bought another $6 chicken during lunch time (should be pretty fresh at this time of day). Went home and found chicken meat to be rubbery and skin so chewy that I cannot break any skin in the box. Believe me, I have good teeth. I was eating that chicken with a friend (who specifically wanted soy sauce chicken for dinner) at home and it was extremely embarrassing. And frustrated again because the same guy who chopped up the meat should know it was very chewy (from the feel of the knife gets into the chicken). I did not go back to ask for a refund. And you know it's fresh because they pull it straight out of the window.

soy sauce chicken.review:
The first time I came to Kam Po h.k.k. (I pretend it stands for Hong Kong Kapaow) I pushed aside the fork in favor of chopsticks which happen to be a far superior eating utensil. I'm not sure if chopsticks are usual fare for non-Chinese people eating in Chinatown, then again I'm not sure if many non-Chinese people eat in Chinatown or H.K.K. for that matter but either way the lady that serves food here seemed quite amused. Since then she has been very friendly, gives me free tea, and always makes it a point to give me chopsticks.

Anyway, the food here is the best, the best Chinese food ever in fact. Try anything that contains the BBQ Pork. I like it in the wonton soup or the China green chow-mien or even just plain by itself. The soy sauce chicken is also delicious as is pretty much anything on the menu. And you know it's fresh because they pull it straight out of the window. Oh and make sure you look at the menu you can hold in your hand rather then the menu on the window because it has more food choices on it.

If I could give a bonus star for every inch of hair that's growing out of the face mole of the meat-chopper guy, I would.

excerpts: The cold boiled chicken is really similar to kainan chicken.
I really like it.
cold boiled chicken.author: Michael N.
cold boiled chicken.review: Yummy. The cold boiled chicken is really similar to kainan chicken. I really like it.

excerpts: Other favorites include: Singapore Style Vermicelli, Beef with Scramble Eggs over rice and Beef Stew Won Ton Noodle Soup
singapore style vermicelli.author: Peter L.
singapore style vermicelli.review:
Kam Po Kitchen's updated their menus for 2010 (see pictures) and now includes clay pot Porridges and clay pot rices.

The prices are a tad higher than before but it's still a great place to go for $5-6! I've never eaten here, but we always order stuff to go every week all year long! Although it can take 30 minutes before it's ready, the clay pot rice dishes are excellent. Their porridges are always a good choice to warm your body.

The Roast Duck, Roast Pork and Soy Sauce Chickens great choices for when you're to lazy to prepare the "meat" at home.

Other favorites include: Singapore Style Vermicelli, Beef with Scramble Eggs over rice and Beef Stew Won Ton Noodle Soup

excerpts: Ordered two type of meat together with rice - roast duck and roast pork.
They give you a lot of meat and rice for $8.80.
The skin of the roast pork was very crispy and the meat is also tender.
roast pork.author: Celine K.
roast pork.review:
Ordered two type of meat together with rice - roast duck and roast pork. They give you a lot of meat and rice for $8.80. The skin of the roast pork was very crispy and the meat is also tender. The sauce they pour over the meat and rice was also good too. 

Do note that this restaurant only accepts cash, and there are limited seats inside.

excerpts: Her Char Siu (rice plate) was better than my Roast Pork
roast pork.author: James G.
roast pork.review:
The old Asian lady next to spoke little-to-no English but still managed to indicate following...

I was using chopsticks correctly
Her Char Siu (rice plate) was better than my Roast Pork
She was enjoying that MJ was enjoying her Roast Duck
She liked Filipinos

Five Stars!

excerpts: Roast Pork: The bubbly crispy exterior is simply amazing!
The meat and fat underneath isn't quite fall part though.
It's firm to the bite, but not too tough.
The whole thing is really good with a little of the chili oil that's on the table.
Only disappointing thing was the inconsistency of the crispy skin; it seemed my table mates got more crispy skin on their plates.
BBQ Pork:
The highly marinated end pieces are the best.
The large leaner pieces are good too, with a nice balance of flavoring.
Wasn't a fan of the fattier pieces since they didn't absorb the marinade as well and the fat seemed tougher than the fat in the roast pork.
roast pork.author: Adam B.
roast pork.review:
On the outskirts of Chinatown, right before the Broadway tunnel brings you to another neighborhood.  Totally worth the hike because there is just so much delicious meat at such a reasonable price.  A very unpretentious place, where office workers can eat beside construction workers.

Roast Pork: The bubbly crispy exterior is simply amazing!  The meat and fat underneath isn't quite fall part though.  It's firm to the bite, but not too tough.  The whole thing is really good with a little of the chili oil that's on the table.  Only disappointing thing was the inconsistency of the crispy skin; it seemed my table mates got more crispy skin on their plates.
 
BBQ Pork: The highly marinated end pieces are the best.  The large leaner pieces are good too, with a nice balance of flavoring.  Wasn't a fan of the fattier pieces since they didn't absorb the marinade as well and the fat seemed tougher than the fat in the roast pork.

Lo Mein: More exciting the white rice.  No flavoring or sauce, but that's ok given how intense the meats are.  Stuck together a bit though.

excerpts: I like the roast pork.
roast pork.author: Kimberly D.
roast pork.review:
My bf loves hainan chicken, so one day we were on yelp searching for this specific dish and we decided to walk to this place to try it out.

This place was very dirty, but the food was really good. Unfortunately, every time we go here since they don't have hainan chicken. They have something similar called Chinese chicken.

My bf is addicted to this place, we go here almost every weekend to get his Chinese chicken with extra ginger. The to go line is actually more expensive than dining in or calling for to go. So we just call in now order to go. I like the roast pork.

excerpts: You could even be extra fancy and get half and half roast pork/cha shu.
roast pork.author: Andrew C.
roast pork.review:
Lol @ the reviews griping about customer service. I mean, bitch, what did you expect? 

Like, it's 2018. You should know you ain't gonna get cloth napkins and indoor voices in a Chinatown establishment. You're lucky that she even brought you the tea. 

Anyways, I love this place. 

Super fast service, and efficient.

And I don't even speak Cantonese properly but that waitress was like that one aunt with RBF that actually loves you deep down.

If you were drawn in by the BBQ, get a BBQ and rice combo. You could even be extra fancy and get half and half roast pork/cha shu. So damn good.

I dunno if it's the same in English but she'll give you a choice between leaner or fattier cuts of pork. 

I'd come back.

excerpts:
Ok, so not friendly but the food...

Awesome; we ordered a half duck and a half pound of roast pork for about $25.
roast pork.author: Kyung E.
roast pork.review:
Awesome takeout roast duck and pork. No English or credit cards allowed. We pointed, paid, and tried to be friendly and were met with some deadpan looks that will stay with me. I almost felt...unwelcome. I stupidly mentioned that we had found them on yelp and we had come all the way from LA to try their duck, and the look they gave me made me feel that I had just pissed all over their grandmothers grave. Ok, so not friendly but the food...

Awesome; we ordered a half duck and a half pound of roast pork for about $25. Both so very good, my mouth is watering thinking about it. The pork skin was crispy and delicious, even cold. 

We took our loot to the hotel room and snacked over the course of a few hours. At no point did it turn and not taste absolutely amazing. Can't wait to come back! Awesome meat for a great price.

excerpts: My go-to items are their chow fun, roast duck, roast pork, and wonton soup.
roast pork.author: Camille L.
roast pork.review:
I LOVE this place. 

It's very convenient to call your order in ten minutes prior, illegally park, then run in to grab your bags of enough food to survive for the next two days, all
for something like $20! 

My go-to items are their chow fun, roast duck, roast pork, and wonton soup.

Sweet customer service goes a long way, too.

excerpts: We had the oh so delicious barbecued roast pork/roast duck (which sold out shortly after we ordered ours), prawns with salt & pepper, and water spinach with preserved tofu.
The roast pork was so crispy!!
Mmmmm.
There's so much on this menu that you'll be sure to find the Chinese dish that you're looking for!
And the prices are not too shabby at all!
My parents have been here as well
so it's a family fave.
Will definitely be coming back for more!
roast pork.author: Monissa W.
roast pork.review: My brother took me here because he knows how much I love BBQ delicacies! Oh man, delicious! We had the oh so delicious barbecued roast pork/roast duck (which sold out shortly after we ordered ours), prawns with salt & pepper, and water spinach with preserved tofu. The roast pork was so crispy!! Mmmmm. There's so much on this menu that you'll be sure to find the Chinese dish that you're looking for! And the prices are not too shabby at all! My parents have been here as well so it's a family fave. Will definitely be coming back for more!

excerpts: The roast pork is also fantastic, same with the fried rice with with scrambled egg and shrimp ( get it with the gravy)
roast pork.author: Matthew W.
roast pork.review:
DO NOT COME HERE. YOU WILL NEVER WANT TO PAY MORE THAN 10 BUCKS FOR ROAST DUCK AGAIN​. The chow mein was also pretty amazing. I wish we got more stuff because​ their menu has an absolutely​ insane spread of dishes (I think we counted like 100+ items). I'm​ coming back here whenever I'm in the city. Great place to eat after day drinking. Cash only though but almost everything is so reasonably​ priced you could put yourself and your date in a diabetic coma for 40 bucks.


I've since returned (while sober even) and the food was still great. The roast pork is also fantastic, same with the fried rice with with scrambled egg and shrimp ( get it with the gravy)

excerpts: The roast pork belly was really good and had a really crispy skin, definitely the best part.
roast pork.author: Clifford M.
roast pork.review: Great pricing and it tasted like homemade Chinese, but better! The roast pork belly was really good and had a really crispy skin, definitely the best part. The roast duck was also delicious. We also had seafood tofu clay pot and the beef stew noodle. Everything hit the spot after a nice long walk. We'll be back when we're in town again!

excerpts: I had the Herbal & Pig Liver Soup & Roast Duck and Roast Pork over Rice.
roast pork.author: Rudy H.
roast pork.review:
one of the most authentic Cantonese kitchen I've been so far.
this place (in terms of ambiance) is a real basic Hong Kong style hole in the wall eatery. 
so, the focus here is the food.
I had the Herbal & Pig Liver Soup & Roast Duck and Roast Pork over Rice.

if you don't speak any Cantonese, just pretend that you're a tourist somewhere in Hong Kong being stranded in alleyways somewhere in Mong Kok, Yau Ma Tei or Sam Shui Po.

big menu, generous portions, hearty and delicious.
I really like this place. 

by the way, it's cash only.

excerpts: Best roast pork
roast pork.author: Vi T.
roast pork.review:
Best roast pork I've ever had (better than Hong Kong too)

Sometimes I'll just look at pictures and reminisce about the good times when I had it

Thank you Kam Po

excerpts: Had a generous portion of roast pork, rice and cabbage for $6.
When you eat there they also offer tea and soup.
roast pork.author: Goldy C.
roast pork.review: Prices are great! Had a generous portion of roast pork, rice and cabbage for $6. When you eat there they also offer tea and soup.

excerpts: We had their roast duck, roast pork, pork fried rice, shrimp fried rice, shrimp wonton soup, and their Chinese broccoli.
Everything was delicious!
For a party of 6, we only paid $57.
roast pork.author: Anna D.
roast pork.review:
If you want to dive into the Chinese culture and surroundings, you must come to Kam Po to eat. We first came here about 10 years ago and have been waiting for the day when we would come back to eat here. It is exactly as I remembered. 

It's a little intimidating when you first walk in here. The customers are mostly local Chinese and a few others who have braved the parking and the streets to try out their food. Don't expect 5 star dining or service. This is a no frills place - you come in, sit down, order and eat. Cash only, by the way. 

We stayed a total of 5 days here in San Francisco, and of all the places we've eaten, this is the one we talked about the most. We had their roast duck, roast pork, pork fried rice, shrimp fried rice, shrimp wonton soup, and their Chinese broccoli. Everything was delicious! For a party of 6, we only paid $57. Most, if not all of their dishes are $6-$8.

After returning from our trip, we were craving Kam Po food, so we ordered from our go-to Chinese restaurant, and nothing comes close. I guess we're going to have to wait for another trip to SF for a visit!

excerpts: Roast pork is just average.
It's a tiny place but service is fast.
They only accept cash.
roast pork.author: Andy V.
roast pork.review: Nice little roast duck and pork restaurant. Roast duck wonton egg noodle soup is grub. The garlic pea sprouts is really tasty. Roast pork is just average. It's a tiny place but service is fast. They only accept cash.

excerpts: TWO BBQ ITEMS WITH RICE - Roast Duck and Roast Pork...
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kam-po-kitchen-san-francisco?select=ZZTE_asvtu5sg-Ilq7tgzQ

)
Compared to my go-to for Chinese BBQ (Cheung Hing), Kam Po holds up pretty well!
While some of the skin could have been crispier, the cut of Roast Pork was fairly thick and didn't have a ton of fat on it.
As for the duck, it was just as good as what I had as a kid - very juicy, luscious, and oh so tender.
roast pork.author: Mike L.
roast pork.review:
While not to the same extent as other parts of the city (hello, Mission), Chinatown has seen its fair share of changes over the years.  Unfortunately (for me), it seems that a lot of those changes have involved the restaurants my relatives and I used to frequent.  Great Wall, Pacific Court Cafe...all gone.  Thank goodness Kam Po is still around though.  It's been a while since I've been back, but my first trip here was over 20 years and they're still going strong!

Stepping inside, Kam Po likely won't impress, save for the tasty looking rack of roasted pork, ducks, and chickens next to the counter (https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kam-po-kitchen-san-francisco?select=GOlu69zPbWbawS0Moe9L2g)  The place is somewhat small, the floors aren't exactly spic-and-span, and the tables have obvious signs of wear and tear.  However, the menu and, more importantly, the food do not disappoint.  The range of offerings may not amaze, but the quality, as well as the cheap prices, definitely stand out!

-- HAINANESE CHICKEN WITH RICE...$5.55
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kam-po-kitchen-san-francisco?select=IMKRS_R8gTerP666h8K6Vg)
Such a large portion for such a tiny price!  The chicken was meaty, tender, and moist and they certainly didn't skimp on the garlic sauce (poured on top rather than on a separate dish).  Plus, there was a lot of pickled vegetables too!  As good as everything was though, I wish the rice itself had a stronger taste of chicken and ginger to it.

-- TWO BBQ ITEMS WITH RICE - Roast Duck and Roast Pork...$8.30
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kam-po-kitchen-san-francisco?select=ZZTE_asvtu5sg-Ilq7tgzQ)
Compared to my go-to for Chinese BBQ (Cheung Hing), Kam Po holds up pretty well!  While some of the skin could have been crispier, the cut of Roast Pork was fairly thick and didn't have a ton of fat on it.  As for the duck, it was just as good as what I had as a kid - very juicy, luscious, and oh so tender.  Plus, the sauce they pour on the meat and rice is so delicious!

Admittedly, had I been on the fence with how many stars to give, I likely would have been a little more generous simply because of all of the memories I have from coming here as a kid (it's been a family favorite ever since my grandfather had moved to Chinatown).  However, I can honestly say I didn't have to in this case.  Sure, I can see why some might not be as enthused as I am, but we've never had any problems here and the food (and value) more than warrant the four star rating.

Thanks, Kam Po, for the delicious comfort food and trip down memory.  Here's to you guys sticking around for another 20+ years!

excerpts: We ordered the roast duck wanton noodles ( turned out to be soup) and roast pork and rice.
Soup and wanton were flavorful.
I wish there were meatier pieces of duck.
The bbq pork was all fat and scarce on meat.
roast pork.author: Joanne N.
roast pork.review:
Was really, and I mean REALLY, looking forward to roast duck. Expectations were high thanks the four stars this place has here on yelp and also cause the roast ducks hanging by the front window made it seem legit. 

We ordered the roast duck wanton noodles ( turned out to be soup) and roast pork and rice. Soup and wanton were flavorful. I wish there were meatier pieces of duck. The bbq pork was all fat and scarce on meat. So all in all, ate a ton of carbs here. 

Service was friendly hence the 3 stars. Also the noodles were pretty good tho not what I came for. And so the search for good roast duck continues.

excerpts: Roast pork noodles - 2 stars.
The roast pork had a thin smooth crust which wasn't what we were looking for.
I guess we envisioned the dim sum roast pork version with the crackled skin.
roast pork.author: Lindt C.
roast pork.review:
Appears to be an authentic Chinese restaurant. 

We had the following for lunch:

Century egg porridge - 4 stars. I've been looking for hearty Cantonese 'zhok' for some time and this hit the spot. It was not too salty and the pork was seasoned just right. Real comfort food in cold weather. 

Roast duck rice - 3 stars. The roast duck was not bad although I think I've had better elsewhere in the city. 

Roast pork noodles - 2 stars. The roast pork had a thin smooth crust which wasn't what we were looking for. I guess we envisioned the dim sum roast pork version with the crackled skin. The noodles were very dry and the cabbage was unfortunately not well-cooked. 

I wanted to like this place since it came with a bit of hype but the roast meats did not live up to expectations for a roast meats restaurant. But portions were huge and very good value for money. I saw a neighbouring table having egg horfun and may try that next time. 

Cash only.

excerpts: My usual is a big plate of roast duck and crispy roast pork over rice for $8.30.
Easily good for two people.
Beef Chow Fun was $5.95 which usually goes for 8 to 11 bucks elsewhere.
Remember old people and blue collar workers are indicating of good plentiful food at a very reasonable price.
roast pork.author: Laurence C.
roast pork.review: Like all things prices goes up but this place still offers one of the best chinese bbq in town at a reasonable price. Remember this is a place to get fed for a cheap price so don't expect fancy surroundings or service. My usual is a big plate of roast duck and crispy roast pork over rice for $8.30. Easily good for two people. Beef Chow Fun was $5.95 which usually goes for 8 to 11 bucks elsewhere.  Remember old people and blue collar workers are indicating of good plentiful food at a very reasonable price.

excerpts: My roast pork didn't taste fresh.
Hubby even sad he wouldn't return.
roast pork.author: Ry T.
roast pork.review: Not a hygienic dining experience as they scored below 90 on healthy inspection.  We stopped in here for a quick lunch which it is not. They only have 2 waitresses and the place was packed. We had to wait for the menu and to order. The portions are generous but the food isn't the best quality. Truly can be described as a greasy spoon. Certainly our noodle dish was ful of oil. My water cup was dirty so I went without liquids with my meal because you can't find a waitress. My roast pork didn't taste fresh.  Hubby even sad he wouldn't return.

excerpts: Be careful when you order roast pork, it is the crunchy lechon style pork hanging by the counter, not the BBQ style pork in the front window.
That is what they call BBQ pork.
roast pork.author: Mabel J.
roast pork.review: My husband and I came here after seeing all the great Yelp reviews and it didn't disappoint. We got in around 3pm and it wasn't packed, but wasn't empty. Service was a little slow, but we weren't in a rush after walking up from Union Square. A nice leisurely late lunch was what we wanted. Portions were super big, which made sense why it was all families and groups besides us. This is the only congee I've ever had that tastes like my Aunt's arroz caldo. It would be exactly like my Aunts if I could still see full rice kernels and if the skin was still on the chicken. Be careful when you order roast pork, it is the crunchy lechon style pork hanging by the counter, not the BBQ style pork in the front window. That is what they call BBQ pork. I ordered the roast duck noodle soup, which came as expected. I wasn't a big fan of the dumplings, but the duck, broth, and noodles more than made up for that. We had so much food leftover, we decided to take it home for dinner. Great value and super good.

excerpts: When I come though I like to ball out a little bit, so I get the rotisserie combo rice plate, but instead of regular chicken I ask for free range, and instead of regular roast pork I ask for the belly ribs, the best part of the roast pig.
This sets you back $13, but it's enough food for two people, and pretty delicious.
If you haven't done this place do it soon, like I said they're quickly dying out!
roast pork.author: Jackson Z.
roast pork.review: Chinatown and SF in general is undergoing a major construction boom, as a result many moms and pops businesses like this one are either going out, or are changing their business model.  This is one of the last of the dying breed, in terms of good quality Cantonese/Chinese food in Chinatown.  They do a good job on Cantonese rotisserie.  Most items are under $10.  When I come though I like to ball out a little bit, so I get the rotisserie combo rice plate, but instead of regular chicken I ask for free range, and instead of regular roast pork I ask for the belly ribs, the best part of the roast pig.  This sets you back $13, but it's enough food for two people, and pretty delicious.  If you haven't done this place do it soon, like I said they're quickly dying out!

excerpts: I know their roast pork is supposed to be famous but at Saturday lunchtime it was not great - dry meat, hard skin (not crispy hard, but hard hard).
roast pork.author: Jean K.
roast pork.review: The bbq pork is still the way to go. I know their roast pork is supposed to be famous but at Saturday lunchtime it was not great - dry meat, hard skin (not crispy hard, but hard hard). The wonton soup with roast duck was okay. Good wontons. Okay roast duck.

excerpts: Ordered the roast duck in wonton noodle soup ($7) but unfortunately 10 minutes into making it they told me they didn't have roast duck anymore and asked if roast pork was fine.
It wasn't really the best alternative but it was still good too.
The soup broth and wontons really made up for it.
roast pork.author: Linda X.
roast pork.review:
CASH ONLY

This is one of my favorite spots for cheap Chinese food! Don't expect anything fancy or the service to be overly friendly and attentive. Yes the server throws menus at you when you sit and you might have to flag them down if you want something but it's all part of the local Chinatown experience. It's more about good cheap food in large quantities.

Ordered the porridge with preserved egg ($3.50). It was served in a massive bowl and was enough for 2 people by itself. Personally I LOVE this dish. It feels so homey and filling. I took my friend who had never had preserved egg before and he really didn't like it so it's definitely an acquired taste.

Ordered the roast duck in wonton noodle soup ($7) but unfortunately 10 minutes into making it they told me they didn't have roast duck anymore and asked if roast pork was fine. It wasn't really the best alternative but it was still good too. The soup broth and wontons really made up for it. You get this giant bowl enough for 2 people on its own!

Overall go for the food and prices not the service.

excerpts: But we ordered roast duck, roast pork, bbq pork, pork intestines, chicken feet, &soy sauce chicken.
When we got home tonight, we had a feast!
roast pork.author: Lihz P.
roast pork.review:
Fairly cheap. Big portions. Quick service! Always packed! So not really great for big groups unless you're willing to wait..

Came in today with my family (party of 10) around 2:30pm and there were no tables open so we waited a good 20-25 minutes before a table opened up. The staff was very nice and quick to let us know it'll be a while until we were seated which was no problem because only half of us were there first. 
--Minus 1 star for all the people who came in after us and seated themselves at random tables instead of waiting to be seated.--
By the time the rest of the party was there it only took us about 5 more minutes until we were seated.

Onto the food... We decided to do family style dinner, so we ordered wonton soup, seafood tofu soup, salted fish fried rice, pan fried house noodles, beef chow fun, roasted pork belly, Garlic Chinese broccoli, garlic water spinach and fish with sweet corn over rice, all to share amongst each other. Everything was really good and our tummies were satisfied! The dish that stood out the most to me was the fish w sweet corn! It sounded weird at first, but don't knock it til you try it!

Obviously, since they sell fresh af Chinese bbq in store as well, we had to buy some to bring home for family dinner! Sadly they didn't have oxtail.. But we ordered roast duck, roast pork, bbq pork, pork intestines, chicken feet, &soy sauce chicken. When we got home tonight, we had a feast! Ate all that with side of baguettes & soy sauce, Vietnamese style! 

This is always my family's go to lunch spot when we're in Chinatown SF. We'll be back soon!

excerpts: We ordered a side of crispy roast pork, because he had never tried it before
and I was curious if it was as good as the one my grandmother used to make or ones I have eaten out at restaurants throughout life.
The pork, I was disappointed.
I think they served us some that had been previously cut, so the meat was a little dry and it was cold-ish.
The skin was oily but not very crispy, lacking the crackle I love so much.
Redemption came in the form of noodles, as we both enjoyed the dishes they brought out.
My friend, unaccustomed to Chinese noodle soups, was surprised to see how bland the broth was in comparison to say pho or ramen.
roast pork.author: Lianna N.
roast pork.review:
To me, Kam Po is exactly what you would expect in any Chinatown. It's a bit off the beaten path, and seemed to house more locals than tourists (aka me). When we entered at 2 for a late lunch, there were no tables available, which made me really excited. Secondly, the staff spoke minimal English, so it seemed more authentic than American. Lastly, like the Chinatown visits of my childhood, roast duck and pork hung in the window and there was a cook with his large cleaver slicing them on his wood stump. All of these things just made me break out into a gigantic grin. 

After a bit of a wait and some awkward waving/eye contact attempts, we were seated crammed in a small table. I opted for the beef tendon noodle soup, and my friend went with the duck noodle soup. We ordered a side of crispy roast pork, because he had never tried it before and I was curious if it was as good as the one my grandmother used to make or ones I have eaten out at restaurants throughout life. The pork, I was disappointed. I think they served us some that had been previously cut, so the meat was a little dry and it was cold-ish. The skin was oily but not very crispy, lacking the crackle I love so much. Redemption came in the form of noodles, as we both enjoyed the dishes they brought out. My friend, unaccustomed to Chinese noodle soups, was surprised to see how bland the broth was in comparison to say pho or ramen. I agreed, but this is the style of the Chinese and what I grew up with, so I still love it dearly along with pho and ramen!

Overall, this is a great place simple place to either dine in or carry out. The meat hanging in the window is chopped for you and weighed per pound, so you can come and try all the varieties of pork, chicken, and duck that your heart desires to go. I especially liked their selections of egg and rice noodle soups with meat.

excerpts: Cheap, quick, and tasty Hong Kong style BBQ : roast pork, BBQ pork, roast duck, etc.
Cash only and probably not the cleanest place but tasty and cheap.
roast pork.author: Aaron H.
roast pork.review: Perfect hole-in-the-wall HKG style BBQ place. Cheap, quick, and tasty Hong Kong style BBQ : roast pork, BBQ pork, roast duck, etc. Cash only and probably not the cleanest place but tasty and cheap.

excerpts: They still had plenty of roast duck, chickens, char siu, roast pork, octopus and all those BBQ foods.
However, hot foods were running low by this time.
It contained very few choices.
roast pork.author: Wendy T.
roast pork.review:
Came in around 6PM on a Thursday. They still had plenty of roast duck, chickens, char siu, roast pork, octopus and all those BBQ foods. However, hot foods were running low by this time. It contained very few choices. Therefore, I got half the guay fay chicken and one pound of octopus.

 Guay fay chicken meat was not at all rough, it was indeed very smooth and very tasty. Didn't even need the oily ginger sauce that I almost always use for my chickens because of the blandness. But this was one of the times that I don't need to dip the chicken in the ginger dip and can still manage to eat the white meat parts. 

Octopus, to me, was average. Nothing special. Nothing horrible. However it was definitely fresh. Also, I think this place is the only place in chinatown that sells octopus. Be sure to stop here if your in chinatown and want some octopus(:

excerpts: Duck, bbq & roast pork (yummy crispy skin!) are good here too.
Always a satisfying experience for us.
roast pork.author: A. C.
roast pork.review: Every time we're in the neighborhood, this is where we go!  Awesome authentic Chinese food and known for all their bbq and roast meat.  Been going to this restaurant for over 20+ yrs and just decided to write a review.  Their food never disappoints, everything is priced reasonably, and you get a ton of food!  We usually end up having leftovers.  No complaints about that.  We always order beef tendon because it's tender and delicious.  Maybe it's not something everyone would eat, but we love how it's made here!  Duck, bbq & roast pork (yummy crispy skin!) are good here too.  Always a satisfying experience for us.

excerpts: Crsipy roast pork was dry and chewy, and the crispy skin was soggy and flavorless.
It was actually kind of bad.
roast pork.author: Marc M.
roast pork.review:
The very windy interior is not the best during cold months. We dropped during the evening when it was a little chilly to find their door propped open and vented windows open as if it were a hot summer's day. Good grief, I'm surprised they can even stand the hilly draft blowing napkins on the floor and chilling you to the bone. They did eventually close the door, but it's still a cold restaurant, so don't how up without warm clothes!

Crsipy roast pork was dry and chewy, and the crispy skin was soggy and flavorless. It was actually kind of bad. I would not recommend this.

The roast duck had an excellent flavor, albeit on the salty side. A shame it was a little bony too. As far as the skin and meat go however, it was tasty.

The wonton soup was a light broth with wonton filled with mushrooms and possibly meat. They had a slight woody flavor that we weren't super excited about, but they are ok.

Rice is a ridiculously cheap, light, and flavorless affair. Unless you are jonesing for rice, this is not the place to get it. Flip side is that they I've you a big bowl of the crap for $1.

excerpts: Ordered 1 lb BBQ pork and 1 lb roast pork to go.
The butcher put together in one box.
It's over 3 lbs total at the end.
roast pork.author: Zack W.
roast pork.review:
Hole on the walls. I like it very much. Come here often.

Clay pot with rice and various meats will take 30-40 min to cook. Gonna try it one day.

Hours are bad sometimes. They closed early a few times.

Communication is not the best with the waitress even in native tongue. She can be argumentative even when she did something wrong.

Ordered 1 lb BBQ pork and 1 lb roast pork to go. The butcher put together in one box. It's over 3 lbs total at the end. She argued the butcher can't be too accurate, right!!!

She asked... I instructed her to separate amount for dine in and 2 separate take outs, but we will pay together in cash. She gave us the total amount only without breakdown. She argued because we wanted to pay together.

Oh well, I can overlook these flaws and still support them.

excerpts: The Soy Sauce Chicken, Roast Pork and Roast Duck - lean and delicious!
roast pork.author: Bennett W.
roast pork.review:
Black Pepper Beef & Rice is delicious. The rice plate serving portion seemed very generous so it's definitely a nice lunch meal. Service is good and some of the staff members here are friendly. There is also a fair amount of seating available if you plan on eating here.

Overall:
- good food
- good prices
- good service
- positive first experience

I'm definitely making my way back for lunch when I am nearby.

*The Soy Sauce Chicken, Roast Pork and Roast Duck - lean and delicious!

excerpts: Small Roast Pork - Small really wasn't all that small.
Probably a good half pound of killer roast pork that came with rice and a side of pickled cabbage.
My thoughts, rich fatty pork, I mean come on, how can it be so good?
roast pork.author: Alexander C.
roast pork.review:
Seriously amazing down home Chinese cookery! There's not much to be said about the decor, its barely clean but if you look beyond the greasy tables and the stacks of old newspapers you'll find one that Kam Po is probably one of the best Chinese places I've tried in Chinatown. 

1/2 Roast Duck - Im a huge addict to great roasted duck, from the crispy skin to the moist fatty meat, there's just something comforting about that smell of five spice that sort of reminds me of autumn. KPK nailed this down! 

Small Roast Pork - Small really wasn't all that small. Probably a good half pound of killer roast pork that came with rice and a side of pickled cabbage. My thoughts, rich fatty pork, I mean come on, how can it be so good? Even the crunchy skin didn't stand a chance against me and my love for pork.

Shrimp Wonton Noodle Soup - About this time our server pushed together another 2 top table against ours. With just the 2 of us ordering so much food, shit just got real. The soup had a good flavor and the chewy shrimp wontons were even better once I adorned them with a whole lot of chili paste. 

Beef Chow Fun - Greasy beefy and awesome! The noodles had a good amount of char and smoke flavor from a wok that's hot as hell. One thing to note is that the portion sizes here are huge and very sharable. 

At this point we were starting to hit the wall. We had chowed like it was our last meal though considering how hung over we were, it might as well have been. With this meal sitting in our bellies our hangovers started to subside. So another insight about KPK, a definite hang over cure.

excerpts: I like their roast pork as well.
roast pork.author: John W.
roast pork.review:
My last meal on Earth would be their roast duck over rice. Good duck with drippings over perfectly done rice at Kam Po is one of my favorite things. I sometimes buy their whole large duck.

I like their roast pork as well. It has good flavor and is one of the better versions that I've found in Chinatown.

Besides the BBQ items it's also generally a good restaurant for Cantonese food.

excerpts: We ordered roast pork and duck.
They taste very bland, but they are at least very cheap.
The shop owner, who received money from a previous customer, obviously thought it was okay to not washing his hands using soap and water.
roast pork.author: Holiday W.
roast pork.review:
We ordered roast pork and duck. They taste very bland, but they are at least very cheap. The shop owner, who received money from a previous customer, obviously thought it was okay to not washing his hands using soap and water. He briefly rinsed his hands using water, and the dried his hands on a towel which looked old and colored, and then chopped up the duck for us.

I have had Peking duck at several restaurants in multiple cities in the U.S. In my opinion, the best one is the Sang Kee Peking Duck in Philadelphia. Kam Po Kitchen ranks towards the bottom on my list.

excerpts: I ordered a roast pork and duck with rice, sure the value is good for the price, but the duck is tough.
Would I come back?
No!!!
roast pork.author: Kevin L.
roast pork.review:
Don't know what the fuss is all about.  The guy who was cutting the meat also handled money without washing his hands.  GROSS!!  

I ordered a roast pork and duck with rice, sure the value is good for the price, but the duck is tough.  Would I come back? No!!!

excerpts: The roast pork wonton noodles were cheap ($6.25 including tax) and generously portioned.
Rice and noodle dishes were even cheaper and looked just as large.
Still, taste was just average.
Moreover, the roast pork was very fatty and some of the wontons had inedible bits in them (likely pieces of shrimp shells).
Overall, meh on a quality scale.
roast pork.author: Vincent L.
roast pork.review:
Kam Po draws a steady stream of Chinatown locals who get fresh barbecued meats to go. As a dine-in place, I can get over the grungy lack of superficial cleanliness (sadly typical of many U.S. Chinatown restaurants, as I'm used to seeing), so I decided to give this place a try based on the high average Yelp rating. 

The roast pork wonton noodles were cheap ($6.25 including tax) and generously portioned. Rice and noodle dishes were even cheaper and looked just as large. Still, taste was just average. Moreover, the roast pork was very fatty and some of the wontons had inedible bits in them (likely pieces of shrimp shells). Overall, meh on a quality scale. To their credit, service was fast and courteous given that I can speak Cantonese. 

Grab your order of barbecued, custom-butchered meats to go, for lunch or dinner at home. If you're conscious about the fat, make sure to trim it out on your own.

excerpts: Their won ton noodles and roast pork/duck are really good too!
roast pork.author: Shanna C.
roast pork.review:
I never realized how great this place was until I went off to college! Everything here is super delicious and cheap! Their seafood jeen meen and beef chow fun (dry or wet) is my all time favorites! Their won ton noodles and roast pork/duck are really good too! There always seem to be a line though!

This is pretty much a hole in the wall place but definitely worth going to try. Authentic chinese food! Can't wait to go back to get some!

excerpts: I mean, they have a dish that has noodles, flat noodles, wontons, and roast pork in soup.
Not a joke.
Food comes out super quickly and piping hot.
Seriously, this place kicks major butt.
It's so small though, so you're going to have to stake out a table if you're coming on a weekend or during rush hour.
roast pork.author: Danny C.
roast pork.review: Kam Po, how do you do it so well? Like everyone says, the bathroom is tiny, service is ridiculous, and it's quite sticky, but man, you're at a Chinese restaurant in Ctown. What are you expecting? Look, their prices haven't changed in years, and you still get the same gigantic portion sizes for $5.88 a plate. This place is seriously ridiculous. I mean, they have a dish that has noodles, flat noodles, wontons, and roast pork in soup. It's $5.88. Not a joke. Food comes out super quickly and piping hot. Seriously, this place kicks major butt. It's so small though, so you're going to have to stake out a table if you're coming on a weekend or during rush hour.

excerpts: We literally went in and ordered roast duck, roast pork, pig feet, chicken feet and steamed rice.
No funny business - just real down to earth good ole grub.
Happily satisfied with promises to come back.
roast pork.author: T C.
roast pork.review: We literally went in and ordered roast duck, roast pork, pig feet, chicken feet and steamed rice. No funny business - just real down to earth good ole grub. Happily satisfied with promises to come back.

excerpts: The roast pork is pretty good and I love their vegetable dishes
but if I were to buy something there again (which I doubt I would), I would eat somewhere else because the environment there is just so unappetizing.
From the sweaty butcher up front with a foot-long hair coming out of his facial mole to the greasy dirty tables and chairs, I'm just not a fan of Kam Po.
Sorry folks.
roast pork.author: Linda H.
roast pork.review:
Ewwww . . . just ewwww . . . 

I love a good deal but there's a sanitary line that I draw in the sand that a restaurant just shouldn't cross and this one does.  By golly, I wish they'd raise the price of all their dishes by a dollar and use the proceeds to buy a bit of hygeine.  

The roast pork is pretty good and I love their vegetable dishes but if I were to buy something there again (which I doubt I would), I would eat somewhere else because the environment there is just so unappetizing.  From the sweaty butcher up front with a foot-long hair coming out of his facial mole to the greasy dirty tables and chairs, I'm just not a fan of Kam Po.  Sorry folks.

excerpts: We ordered beef chow fun, wonton soup with roast pork, and rice plate 1/2 duck 1/2 pork, it was all very good and CHEAP!
roast pork.author: Shawn G.
roast pork.review:
Last night in SF we went here for dinner. Seated quickly, waitress was a little abrupt and was sure to tell us cash only before taking our order. The place was full and there was only the one extremely busy waitress. Also it seemed strange they did not have ice. 

We ordered beef chow fun, wonton soup with roast pork, and rice plate 1/2 duck 1/2 pork, it was all very good and CHEAP!

excerpts: I'd dropped into Kam Po several times over the past few years to pick up components for dinner, such as some chopped up roast pork or a box of steamed rice, but I had never tried anything off the menu.
roast pork.author: Valeria R.
roast pork.review:
Hot diggity duck!

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0Yw-OWhZAU8BI852cx21ug?select=4pgA69Ao2Eth6PuchWOdXQ

I'd dropped into Kam Po several times over the past few years to pick up components for dinner, such as some chopped up roast pork or a box of steamed rice, but I had never tried anything off the menu.

I finally had my chance when I was working nearby yesterday. I walked in at lunchtime and stopped in my tracks...why had I never noticed before that the big menu on the wall is only in Chinese?

I started scoping out what the 99% Chinese patrons and 1% smart tourists had on their tables and kept going back to the roast duck that an older gentleman seemed to be greatly relishing.

Wow. So incredibly flavorful. The accompanying steamed cabbage and white rice picked up the wonderfully rich brown sauce from the duck, and the duck itself was moist, tender, fatty goodness.

I came thisclose to stopping back in later for another order for dinner but decided to wait. I'll leave the memory of that velvety duck percolating in my mind for another few days...let the anticipation build up. That way it'll feel like the first time all over again.

excerpts: The duck and roast pork from kam po is my favorite in all of the Bay Area.
Can't beat the prices of this historic Chinatown spot.
roast pork.author: Dylan M.
roast pork.review: I've been coming here since I was an infant.  It's a family favorite and I appreciate that in the past 20+ years I've been a customer -- not much has changed.  The duck and roast pork from kam po is my favorite in all of the Bay Area.  Can't beat the prices of this historic Chinatown spot.

excerpts: But if you can get over that hurl, I meant "hurdle",  the duck, roast pork and the bbq pork is what's popular here.
We also like to order the curry Singapore Rice noodles, you order this and other menu dishes from the Lady, not with Mr. Cleaver.
Mr. Cleaver, the deli guy with the stern look, he doesn't like anyone, so don't take it personally.
Here's how you can have a smooth transaction:
Know which cut of meat you would like before you get up to him.
Would you like your pork fatty,  a bit fatty or with little fat
, do you want a young duck or a large duck.
Just to let you know, a little fatty on the pork is the better choice of the three.
Have your money out, the longer you take the greasier
your bag will be when he hands it to you.
It's a sick game, and I know it's "fowl"  here, but they do good chinese bbq here.
roast pork.author: Chris O.
roast pork.review: Here's the dirty on this place:  It's dirty.  But if you can get over that hurl, I meant "hurdle",  the duck, roast pork and the bbq pork is what's popular here.  We also like to order the curry Singapore Rice noodles, you order this and other menu dishes from the Lady, not with Mr. Cleaver.  Mr. Cleaver, the deli guy with the stern look, he doesn't like anyone, so don't take it personally.  Here's how you can have a smooth transaction: Know which cut of meat you would like before you get up to him. Would you like your pork fatty,  a bit fatty or with little fat, do you want a young duck or a large duck.  Just to let you know, a little fatty on the pork is the better choice of the three.  Have your money out, the longer you take the greasier your bag will be when he hands it to you.  It's a sick game, and I know it's "fowl"  here, but they do good chinese bbq here.

excerpts: The roast pork lo mein!
The roast pork is super tasty and I love crackled skin; simply amazing.
The lo mein noodles come with oyster sauce and some steamed cabbage and a side soup.

The soup seems to be whatever extra pieces of whatever they have lying around thrown into a broth; sometimes it's just a broth with a  few pieces of unidentifiable goodness, other times it's packed with unidentifiable goodness.
but I always come back for the roast pork.
roast pork.author: D D.
roast pork.review:
My "other" go to place in china town...

I usually go to Yee's because it's closer to work and I dig their happy hour but sometimes I'll trek the extra couple of blocks to Kam Po.

First of all, Kam Po is almost always busy and there's little space; it's a squeeze to get in most of the time and if you are a larger person I would avoid it altogether.  Second; this place is pretty dirty, I haven't gotten sick yet (I eat here about twice a month) but if dingy restaurants are a turn off than don't bother.

So, why five stars?  The food is awesome and relatively cheap.

My favorite?  The roast pork lo mein!  The roast pork is super tasty and I love crackled skin; simply amazing.  The lo mein noodles come with oyster sauce and some steamed cabbage and a side soup.  The soup seems to be whatever extra pieces of whatever they have lying around thrown into a broth; sometimes it's just a broth with a  few pieces of unidentifiable goodness, other times it's packed with unidentifiable goodness. It think it's $5.60 or something; awesome meal.

I've tried their other stuff and it's all good; congee, noodle soups, etc. etc. but I always come back for the roast pork.

If you are an adventurous eater, enjoy real chinese food, and can put up with a dingy crowded restaurant than this place is for you; it's a genuine hole-in the wall treasure.  If you're looking for fine dining, keep walking.

excerpts: Roast Pork = Incredible.
The skin was perfectly crispy and the meat was unbelievably tender and juicy.
We got there a little late, so the meat was a little cold from hanging on the hook throughout the morning, but the juiciness wasn't compromised in any way.
roast pork.author: Roy C.
roast pork.review:
This is my new favorite Cantonese restaurant in SF. It reminds me so much of the dirty and grungy restaurants that I frequented when I lived in China -- none of which would ever pass a standard health inspection, but all of which are always crowded because of authentic, delicious Chinese food at outrageously low prices.

If you can stomach the unsanitary environment (including very questionable silverware -- e.g., deep brown stains on white soup spoons) and don't mind stuffing yourself into a crowded, loud space (during weekend lunch rush hours), then you're in for quite a treat at Kam Po. 

I'm actually surprised at how good the service is here -- on the surface, Kam Po should have the laughably-horrible customer service that we've all come to accept and love from Chinatown restaurants. The two waitresses were unbelievably busy, but always made time to come fill up our tea and bring us whatever we wanted. They even cracked a smile once or twice.

The most entertaining spectacle of the restaurant, however, is the butcher behind the counter, elevated as if on a stage. This is someone who possesses a razor-sharp butcher knife as an extension of his arm, slicing and chopping through pork ribs and duck necks in a way that looked strangely artistic. You could imagine a Beethoven symphony playing in the background as he beautifully butchers the back bones of a suckling pig. Benihana performances ain't got nothing on Kam Po. 

--------------------------------------

FOOD:

Roast Pork = Incredible. The skin was perfectly crispy and the meat was unbelievably tender and juicy. We got there a little late, so the meat was a little cold from hanging on the hook throughout the morning, but the juiciness wasn't compromised in any way. I can only imagine how delicious it must be immediately after cooking.

Roast Duck = Pretty good. I'm more of a fan of the Beijing-style roast duck with the crispy skin than this kind, where the skin is soggy from sweet and sour sauce. The meat was very tender, but I just don't really like having it drenched in so much sauce.

Preserved Egg & Pork Porridge = Possibly the best preserved egg porridge I've had in San Francisco. There are so many full flavors packed into this porridge that it makes every bite delicious.

Garlic Sauteed Pea Shoots = Loved it. It's a little oily, but the garlic flavors explode with each bite. The pea shoots are very nicely stir-fried, without being overcooked like they usually are. Keep in mind that it's actually pretty-hilariously written in Chinglish as "Garlic Pea Sharts" on the menu. I want to give Kam Po an extra star just for that.

Total: $20 after tax & tip. Yes, it was seriously that cheap.

--------------------------------------

Kam Po is like a wonderful slice of the true Chinese neighborhood experience. I've tried many restaurants and delis in Chinatown whose food is comparable to (and probably even better than) that of Kam Po, but Kam Po definitely delivers the full experience that I love most about Chinese restaurants.

excerpts: The best roast duck and roast pork in Chinatown.
The Chow fun and HK style pan fried noodles (chow mein) are top notch too.
roast pork.author: Paul L.
roast pork.review: The best roast duck and roast pork in Chinatown. The Chow fun and HK style pan fried noodles (chow mein) are top notch too. Very good Wonton, meaty morsels wrapped in just the right thickness of Wonton skin. Atmosphere for dining is undesirable, prefer to order to go. The food is actually deserving of 4.5 star rating.

excerpts: The best is the roast pork and the FRIED RICE!
Omg, the aromas of all the meats mixed together with the rice makes me drool every time.
At $4 a rice plate, you really wonder if they are even making a profit.
So cheap!
roast pork.author: Sally C.
roast pork.review:
I always always always come back to Kam Po for lunch whenever I'm in Chinatown. Even if I'm stopping by, I'll get a box to go. The best is the roast pork and the FRIED RICE! Omg, the aromas of all the meats mixed together with the rice makes me drool every time. At $4 a rice plate, you really wonder if they are even making a profit. So cheap! And they give you a lot of rice and a side of veggies AND delicious complimentary soup.

Don't come expecting excellent service or anything- the restaurant is CROWDED. You'll be sitting with other people, your tables are less than a foot away, and it'll get awkward. But it's all a part of the experience! Sit down, don't put your bags in the aisles, shut up, and eat your food. It's Chinatown.

excerpts: Kam Po is definitely my go-to spot when I'm hankering for roast duck, roast pork, bbq pork, or any other culinary treat that can be hooked and dangled in front of a window.
In particular the roast duck wonton noodle soup is my favorite in the city.

The wontons are super flavorful, perfect ration of meat to wrapper without that weird gummy consistency, and don't make me feel like I'm eating dumpling bought from Costco; and they are definitely not at all skimpy on the roast duck portion which is more than generous.
roast pork.author: David H.
roast pork.review:
There are two things for certain when coming to Kam Po: 1) you'll probably be eating at a greasy-looking table wiped down by a towel about 3 months past its prime; 2) the food will be ridiculously good. So if you can overlook #1 (when did we all become such sissies in SF?), then you're in for a treat.

Kam Po is definitely my go-to spot when I'm hankering for roast duck, roast pork, bbq pork, or any other culinary treat that can be hooked and dangled in front of a window. In particular the roast duck wonton noodle soup is my favorite in the city. The wontons are super flavorful, perfect ration of meat to wrapper without that weird gummy consistency, and don't make me feel like I'm eating dumpling bought from Costco; and they are definitely not at all skimpy on the roast duck portion which is more than generous.

Kam Po is one of those places that actually feels and looks like what one would imagine to be an authentic Chinatown restaurant.

Looking forward to my next bowl of soup!

excerpts: I had two cubes of their roast pork
roast pork.author: Lolia S.
roast pork.review:
