Crazy cheap Hong Kong BBQ joint!  I was afraid to order the congee (they have a dozen kinds) because it was so cheap (under $3) and no one had ordered any.  Rice and noodle plates seemed to be the most popular items.  You can get pig's feet, organs, kidney, tendon and liver.  We shared a table with a guy who was digging into beef & bittermelon with rice.  It's a full size dish for $3.50!  And you get free hot tea.  Don B. accidentally drank someone else's tea!

I ordered dumplings ($3) figuring that was a safe bet.  You get 7 large dumplings, some bok choy and a shrimpy broth.  The dumplings had very thin skins and they were filled with chopped shrimp, wood ear fungus, bamboo shoots, chives, etc.  They were good but I was hoping for juicy pork dumplings.  These weren't juicy.  I had two cubes of their roast pork - one piece was very chewy and dry and the other was pretty good.  

It looks like Kam Po has been here forever.  They've got ducks and pigs hanging in the BBQ area.  People share sticky tables in close proximity and the place is filled with Cantonese (locals I presume).  A true hole in the wall. I gave them another star just for their prices. It must be cash only.

excerpts: The Roast Duck, Roast Pork and Soy Sauce
roast pork.author: Peter L.
roast pork.review:
Kam Po Kitchen's updated their menus for 2010 (see pictures) and now includes clay pot Porridges and clay pot rices.

The prices are a tad higher than before but it's still a great place to go for $5-6! I've never eaten here, but we always order stuff to go every week all year long! Although it can take 30 minutes before it's ready, the clay pot rice dishes are excellent. Their porridges are always a good choice to warm your body.

The Roast Duck, Roast Pork and Soy Sauce Chickens great choices for when you're to lazy to prepare the "meat" at home.

Other favorites include: Singapore Style Vermicelli, Beef with Scramble Eggs over rice and Beef Stew Won Ton Noodle Soup

excerpts: The roast pork was very fatty and juicy.
roast pork.author: Tina W.
roast pork.review: If you're looking for a cheap chinese meal, this is the place to go. The portions are also quite big considering the amount you pay.  The roast pork was very fatty and juicy. However, the wonton skin was not as silky smooth as I normally prefer.

excerpts: A Chinatown staple for roast pork, roast duck and bbq pork.
Each of the meats were tender and flavorful.
They are familiar to my taste buds and comforting to my tummy.
The bbq meat order comes with a huge serving of rice, meat and veggies.
They will ladle sauce over it.
Cheap comfort food that opens til 8 pm.
roast pork.author: Eve C.
roast pork.review: So cheap and good. A Chinatown staple for roast pork, roast duck and bbq pork. Each of the meats were tender and flavorful. They are familiar to my taste buds and comforting to my tummy. The bbq meat order comes with a huge serving of rice, meat and veggies. They will ladle sauce over it. Cheap comfort food that opens til 8 pm.

excerpts: My mom got the rice with roast pork.
It was good, but can't compete with the duck.
Service was good.
Everyone else dining there was Chinese.
Seems like an authentic place.
roast pork.author: Susan P.
roast pork.review: I ordered the rice with roast duck.  It was awesome!  Very tender and flavorful duck.  The meal also came with soup and some cabbage.  My mom got the rice with roast pork.  It was good, but can't compete with the duck.  Service was good.  Everyone else dining there was Chinese. Seems like an authentic place.

excerpts: Now I'm craving their "syu yok ap fan" (BBQ roast pork, roast duck combo rice plate lunch) and it's 1AM!!
What do I do now?!
Can't wait till tomorrow lunch.
GOOD FOOD.
nuff said.
roast pork.author: George F.
roast pork.review: Like eating at grandma's house. Everything fresh, piping hot, delicious, home cooked traditional Cantonese "comfort food." Inexpensive, fast, real. Consistent over the years. Their Cantonese BBQ is one of the best. Eaten here hundreds of times with my fam and friends and NEVER DISAPPOINTED. Good food, Aww shoot. Now I'm craving their "syu yok ap fan" (BBQ roast pork, roast duck combo rice plate lunch) and it's 1AM!! What do I do now?! Can't wait till tomorrow lunch. GOOD FOOD. nuff said.

excerpts: the soup noodles are top notch - we had bbq pork spareribs with noodles, and crispy roast pork with wonton mein.
both items were under $5 (each was $6 including tip).
roast pork.author: Jason J.
roast pork.review:
another 5 star review for food only.  

chinese people get scared away by this place - so this is a warning to all non chinese people - this is a hole in the wall.  its been this way for years, and the food is excellent.  ignore the fact that it looks "gross" (aka normal chinatown).

the service is fast, done by one gal who is pretty damn good at her job.

the soup noodles are top notch - we had bbq pork spareribs with noodles, and crispy roast pork with wonton mein.  both items were under $5 (each was $6 including tip).

excerpts: They served cold roast pork and duck.
When these items are served cold the fat is disgusting.
I'm always sweating so my fat is nice and soft.
Getting a table is a shit show.
+1 star for the price.
roast pork.author: Fatty A.
roast pork.review: The place is crazy cheap for food.  You may get food poisoning but its cheap!  Most dishes are $5.  The BBQ meats are kinda gross though.  The duck is good as long as its warm.  They served cold roast pork and duck.  When these items are served cold the fat is disgusting.  I'm always sweating so my fat is nice and soft.  Getting a table is a shit show.  +1 star for the price.

excerpts: The roast pork I had was a bit dry, so I'll probably have to try it again to see if its just a one time incident.
Yeah, the restaurant is dirty and the tables and chairs are sticky; what else would you expect.
roast pork.author: Jun W.
roast pork.review:
Huge portion of roast meat on rice for $7. The duck is delicious and fatty. The roast pork I had was a bit dry, so I'll probably have to try it again to see if its just a one time incident. 
Yeah, the restaurant is dirty and the tables and chairs are sticky; what else would you expect.

excerpts: I ordered the Roast Pork... LOVED IT!
it was so flavorful, juicy, and
roast pork.author: Elsa Y.
roast pork.review:
I ordered the Roast Pork... LOVED IT! it was so flavorful, juicy, and the skin was still crispy after about 2 hours sitting in the car. 

The cha-sui was a little too fatty, next time I'll ask for non-fat instead of half and half. 

The location is good and the bbq  is cheap.

excerpts: The grandmas and grandpas in chinatown who frequent this joint don't seem to mind the presentation but they definitely won't tolerate anything that is less than perfect roast duck, roast pork, BBQ pork, or won ton noodle.
At least that is my theory as to why their signature food is so good.
roast pork.author: perry h.
roast pork.review:
Ambiance : -2.5 stars  (yes, minus 2.5)
Cleanliness : -2.5 stars (another minus)
Roast Duck over rice :  10 stars (a TEN? yes, indeed...)

So, they add up to 5 stars. 

This is one of those hole-in-the wall in SF chinatown that offer generous portion of authentic cantonese food for a bargain.  The grandmas and grandpas in chinatown who frequent this joint don't seem to mind the presentation but they definitely won't tolerate anything that is less than perfect roast duck, roast pork, BBQ pork, or won ton noodle.  At least that is my theory as to why their signature food is so good.

excerpts: We had: roast pork and rice, roast duck noodle soup, and beef and tofu over rice.
The beef and tofu was average, but the roast meat items were standouts.
Looking around, I knew the place was legit because we were surrounded by old Chinese people.
Each item was less than $5.
Service was super fast, though not exactly friendly.
roast pork.author: Jennifer K.
roast pork.review:
Quintessential hole in the wall...and it was delicious. 

We had: roast pork and rice, roast duck noodle soup, and beef and tofu over rice. The beef and tofu was average, but the roast meat items were standouts. Looking around, I knew the place was legit because we were surrounded by old Chinese people.  Each item was less than $5. Service was super fast, though not exactly friendly. Whatever though, you come to this place for the food - especially the roasted meats. 

Can't wait to come back again!

excerpts: Really really good roast pork over rice.
The price is a deal and you will be full hours later.
The pork is moist, tender, and flavorful.
Even the cabbage is so tasty.
Be warned.
This is a local's place.
Don't be afraid that almost everything is in Chinese on the wall.
There is an english menu.
They do understand what is on the menu.
Oh, and a tip.
Make sure you know what you want before you go in.
It's crowded and busy.
Everybody wants their food right now.
roast pork.author: Jack R.
roast pork.review: Really really good roast pork over rice.  The price is a deal and you will be full hours later.  The pork is moist, tender, and flavorful.  Even the cabbage is so tasty.  Be warned.  This is a local's place.  Don't be afraid that almost everything is in Chinese on the wall.  There is an english menu.   They do understand what is on the menu.  Oh, and a tip.  Make sure you know what you want before you go in.  It's crowded and busy.  Everybody wants their food right now.

excerpts: I've only had the roast pork (siu yuk) wonton noodle soup.
It's a pretty filling bowl with several wontons and a lot of roast pork.
It's a pretty good deal because I paid about $8 after tip.
There's actually quite a huge selection of different dishes... vegetables, rice, meats... pretty much all the standard cantonese foods.
The best part about the restaurant is sitting inside facing the counter, and watching everyone at work.
There's usually one waitress around who always has a smile on her face.
There's another tough looking woman, whose duties revolve around managing the money, the chopping block, and serving customers.
She seems like a real strict boss type, but after a while of watching her at work, you'll soon come to see that she's just a really hard-working person who means well.
Finally, there's butcher who is never without his cleaver.
He might be handling money when he's the only guy behind the counter, but don't misunderstand.
He's here to take care of all the meat, from the roast ducks behind the window to the huge slab of siu yuk hanging as the centerpiece of the room.
Everything about him from his physical appearance, demeanor, and his skill with the cleaver indicates that he is the embodiment of the original chinese deli butcher.
Come if you're interested in some nice chinese food with some real characters to observe while you eat.
roast pork.author: Andrew S.
roast pork.review: I've only had the roast pork (siu yuk) wonton noodle soup. It's a pretty filling bowl with several wontons and a lot of roast pork. It's a pretty good deal because I paid about $8 after tip. There's actually quite a huge selection of different dishes... vegetables, rice, meats... pretty much all the standard cantonese foods. The best part about the restaurant is sitting inside facing the counter, and watching everyone at work. There's usually one waitress around who always has a smile on her face. There's another tough looking woman, whose duties revolve around managing the money, the chopping block, and serving customers. She seems like a real strict boss type, but after a while of watching her at work, you'll soon come to see that she's just a really hard-working person who means well. Finally, there's butcher who is never without his cleaver. He might be handling money when he's the only guy behind the counter, but don't misunderstand. He's here to take care of all the meat, from the roast ducks behind the window to the huge slab of siu yuk hanging as the centerpiece of the room. Everything about him from his physical appearance, demeanor, and his skill with the cleaver indicates that he is the embodiment of the original chinese deli butcher. Come if you're interested in some nice chinese food with some real characters to observe while you eat.

excerpts: The broth on the soup was awesome, the wontons were good (not great because I have had better but for 4 bucks what can you say), the roast pork and roast duck were killer!!!
roast pork.author: jason g.
roast pork.review:
hahahahah...........this has to go to my list of 5 star food at 1 star places.  I haven't been here since I was a kid.  

I came here with my old roommate because it was close by and the food here is good and cheap.  I think I saw an order on the menu that was around 2.60.  I couldn't believe my eyes.  As for the food, it is pretty damn good for a hole in a wall Chinatown restaurant.  The broth on the soup was awesome, the wontons were good (not great because I have had better but for 4 bucks what can you say), the roast pork and roast duck were killer!!!

I need to start coming back to Chinatown to eat more often.  It's sorta an adventure when you haven't eaten here for a while.  I will definitely come back to this place.

excerpts: Prices were very reasonable; our party of three ordered a roast pork and duck rice, a soy sauce chicken rice, beef chow fun, and a seafood tofu clay pot, and that came out to be around 25 dollars (plus a lot of leftovers enough for a second meal)!
The roast pork was crispy on the outside, and both the duck meat and chicken were tender and juicy.
Since being a legit Chinese restaurant, service wasn't the best, but we got our food in a timely manner (and the waitress seemed overwhelmed manning the whole store by herself).
Would come back again if I go back to SF!
roast pork.author: Raymond C.
roast pork.review: Came here since I was in SF and wanted some legit Canto food. Prices were very reasonable; our party of three ordered a roast pork and duck rice, a soy sauce chicken rice, beef chow fun, and a seafood tofu clay pot, and that came out to be around 25 dollars (plus a lot of leftovers enough for a second meal)! The roast pork was crispy on the outside, and both the duck meat and chicken were tender and juicy. Since being a legit Chinese restaurant, service wasn't the best, but we got our food in a timely manner (and the waitress seemed overwhelmed manning the whole store by herself). Would come back again if I go back to SF!

excerpts: My friends and I always come here if we want some good roast duck or roast pork over rice.
roast pork.author: Jenny Y.
roast pork.review:
I love it here! My friends and I always come here if we want some good roast duck or roast pork over rice. Seriously, for $5 you can get that. 

This place is always PACKED! 

I remember I used to come here a lot when I was young, then I stopped because my mother got into the whole health trend. But now, screw that, I want me some crispy duck skin.

Here are a few tips if you decide to go to this restaurant:
1. Be aggressive. Don't wait around for them to notice you. Once they see you, let them know you are here and how many people you have.
2. Don't drink too much of the tea. I'm not saying the tea is dirty (it might be), but this will help you NOT use their bathroom.
3. The only things that should be ordered here are rice plates paired with some sort of roasted meat and crispy noodles.
4. Don't sit and chat with your friends like this is some sort of cafe. It's not. People around you will think you look stupid.
5. Bring your own bottle of water. 
6. Respect the waitress. She works here 7 days a week during all the hours that this restaurant is opened. She's the first one here and the last one to leave. Cut her some slack.

excerpts: Their roast pork and BBQ pork are both pretty good .
Their chicken leg is not ...
it's very dry and lacks flavor .
roast pork.author: Eileen L.
roast pork.review: Their roast pork and BBQ pork are both pretty good . Their chicken leg is not ... it's very dry and lacks flavor . Will be back to try their chicken and roast duck .

excerpts: But I do know they've got some of the best damn Roast Duck & Roast Pork in Chinatown because...

all I do is ask for a half order of Roast Duck & Roast Pork over steamed rice, TO GO, and the fellas grab the duck & pork off their respective hooks, place em on the cutting block, and do what I can only describe as... well...

all I do is ask for a half order of Roast Duck & Roast Pork over steamed rice, TO GO, and the fellas grab the duck & pork off their respective hooks, place em on the cutting block, and do what I can only describe as... well...
roast pork.author: John Eric S.
roast pork.review:
I'm not sure if Kam Po even has a menu printed in English. They certainly have lots of things written in Chinese taped up in their windows and along their walls.

And I have never eaten INSIDE the restaurant. Always ordered TO GO.

But I do know they've got some of the best damn Roast Duck & Roast Pork in Chinatown because... well... it's hanging right there in the window!

I don't think the fellas with the meat cleavers that work behind the counter speak much English, but we've developed an almost unspoken understanding over the years... all I do is ask for a half order of Roast Duck & Roast Pork over steamed rice, TO GO, and the fellas grab the duck & pork off their respective hooks, place em on the cutting block, and do what I can only describe as... well... *MAGIC* with that meat cleaver!

All this food & the show for just $6? That's one of the best deals in town, my friends.

excerpts: Whether it's wonton and roast pork noodle soup or a soy sauce chicken rice dish, you get gigantic portions (that to a normal person is two servings, but I tend to eat a lot).
That's not all as well,
before you get your entree you get a bowl of delicious homemade soup.
roast pork.author: Jon W.
roast pork.review:
I'm amazed that I haven't reviewed this place until now, because, really, when it comes to affordable Chinese restaurants you can't get better than big portions + good food + bare basement prices. Whether it's wonton and roast pork noodle soup or a soy sauce chicken rice dish, you get gigantic portions (that to a normal person is two servings, but I tend to eat a lot). That's not all as well, before you get your entree you get a bowl of delicious homemade soup. All that for less than $6 (I wish I could get anything for less than $6 now that I live in DC)

Okay, so the place may not be the most sanitary of places. The tables are pretty cramped and during busy times you'll have to share. And yes, it's cash only (but that's pretty much anywhere in Chinatown anyways). But really, all that is worth it for the lipsmaking goodness coming your way at Kam Po. I'm definitely looking forward to coming back to San Francisco again and eating another delicious meal here.

excerpts: The roast pork and peking duck is excellent!
I usually get their special for dinner which is 3 full entree with rice and soup for $18.99!
roast pork.author: Jo S.
roast pork.review:
This is one of my favorite hole in the wall restaurants for lunch/dinner in Chinatown.  

The roast pork and peking duck is excellent!  I usually get their special for dinner which is 3 full entree with rice and soup for $18.99!  You cannot beat this price and quality at any other Chinese restaurant.  

Definitely check this place out!

excerpts: Roast Pork/Roast Duck Combo!
$7.45 and well worth it.
It's always a bit cheaper when you get just one item alone but as a carnivore, the combo for me is a must.
What has me praising this place is the portions and pricing...
two things that pair together well when used right.
Look past the "greasy spoon" ambience at this place and try it out!
You're guaranteed to keep your tummy and your wallet full.
Great Food!
And for those of you adventerouse eaters...go ahead and try your hand at the pig intestines, or maybe some chicken feet, but the roast pork or duck here is the staple!
RECOMMENDED
roast pork.author: Marcel W.
roast pork.review: Roast Pork/Roast Duck Combo! $7.45 and well worth it. It's always a bit cheaper when you get just one item alone but as a carnivore, the combo for me is a must. What has me praising this place is the portions and pricing...two things that pair together well when used right. Look past the "greasy spoon" ambience at this place and try it out! You're guaranteed to keep your tummy and your wallet full. Great Food! And for those of you adventerouse eaters...go ahead and try your hand at the pig intestines, or maybe some chicken feet, but the roast pork or duck here is the staple! RECOMMENDED

excerpts: This was actually the 2nd day in a row I stopped by for roast duck on rice with roast pork for variety ... parking is such a bee-ach and those hot foods on display in the front are rather beckoning
but it's pretty much a HK barbecue charcuterie to go for me ... as far as dining in goes, well
yeah, decor leaves a lot to be desired but the prices offset that demerit
so it's still one of those San Francisco treasures and the place to grab roast ducks,
copious portions of roast pork, char siu, roast and boiled chickens, etc.
Heard those used to have roast goose
and now I have kind of a hankering for that ...
last time I had it was in Dong Guan
and it was memorably good ...
Kam Po Kitchen, the food's a steal, real deal and
you will feel duck satiatied in the best of ways ...
roast pork.author: Terry A.
roast pork.review: Wow, the char siu and roast duck over rice that we just ate was humongous ... LEAN duck, what's the secret?  Unlike Cheung Hing's and a few others I could mention, Kam Po's really got the roast duck down to lucious, lean duckie goodness ... it's like when you get a hunk of  crab claw meat on your Swan Oyster Depot salad and you get a nice mouthful of pure "MEAT" and it's culinary oral orgasm ... *satisfied smile* then gourmand after glow ... This was actually the 2nd day in a row I stopped by for roast duck on rice with roast pork for variety ... parking is such a bee-ach and those hot foods on display in the front are rather beckoning but it's pretty much a HK barbecue charcuterie to go for me ... as far as dining in goes, well yeah, decor leaves a lot to be desired but the prices offset that demerit so it's still one of those San Francisco treasures and the place to grab roast ducks, copious portions of roast pork, char siu, roast and boiled chickens, etc.  Heard those used to have roast goose and now I have kind of a hankering for that ... last time I had it was in Dong Guan and it was memorably good ... Kam Po Kitchen, the food's a steal, real deal and you will feel duck satiatied in the best of ways ...

excerpts: Any dish with the BBQ meats that are on display up front will be a tasty bargain - roast pork (crispy skin), BBQ pork (that's cha siu), and roast duck are the three main ones.
roast pork.author: Oh G.
roast pork.review:
This restaurant is the very definition of good, authentic, cheap Chinese food. I love the noodle soups but the full panoply of fast Cantonese rice and noodle dishes is available. Any dish with the BBQ meats that are on display up front will be a tasty bargain - roast pork (crispy skin), BBQ pork (that's cha siu), and roast duck are the three main ones.

The lady who seems to be there all the time is amazing - she doesn't need to write down your order and she always gets it right. She has amazing energy to keep going at all times of the day. She's my hero.

There's an English menu, but there's also Chinese language signs on the walls. I can read Chinese, but I've  never ordered the Chinese-only dishes - just because they feature things like frog and bitter melon that I really don't like anyway. If you want to be adventurous, tell her you want to try one of them - it won't cost much!

The place is small and the bare tables are packed in together with little elbow room. But that's part of the appeal, for me. No pretension, no creature comforts - just delicious cheap food.

excerpts: The roast pork looked good even from my car in the street
so I am looking forward to going back to try that.
roast pork.author: Mike Y.
roast pork.review: All I got was the roast duck and the BBQ pork, and both were good.  The duck was most likely fresh as it was a nice combination of fatty and crispy.  BBQ pork was about as good as I would expect from a BBQ place like this, nothing super extraordinary.  This is a hole in the wall type of joint where you can expect cheap food that has good quality.  Caveat: I have never actually gone into the restaurant (just dropped off people to pick up the duck), but I think this is probably the best way to go so that you can avoid both the hellish parking in the Chinatown area as well as the crowded restaurant.  The roast pork looked good even from my car in the street so I am looking forward to going back to try that.

excerpts: Ordered two type of meat together with rice - roast duck and roast pork.
They give you a lot of meat and rice for $8.80.
The skin of the roast pork was very crispy and the meat is also tender.
roast duck.author: Celine K.
roast duck.review:
Ordered two type of meat together with rice - roast duck and roast pork. They give you a lot of meat and rice for $8.80. The skin of the roast pork was very crispy and the meat is also tender. The sauce they pour over the meat and rice was also good too. 

Do note that this restaurant only accepts cash, and there are limited seats inside.

excerpts: She was enjoying that MJ was enjoying her Roast Duck
roast duck.author: James G.
roast duck.review:
The old Asian lady next to spoke little-to-no English but still managed to indicate following...

I was using chopsticks correctly
Her Char Siu (rice plate) was better than my Roast Pork
She was enjoying that MJ was enjoying her Roast Duck
She liked Filipinos

Five Stars!

excerpts: Kam Po Kitchen offers sit-down meal service or a take-out line for those who wish to bring home roast duck, soy sauce chicken or any meat of the sort.
Roast duck over rice, duck wonton soup and prawn with egg chow fun are all good choices.
Everything is also inexpensive.
Unlike many of the butcher shops in Chinatown, Kam Po does not skimp out on the meat.
roast duck.author: Philip M.
roast duck.review:
everything is so darn good here.

Kam Po Kitchen doesn't serve up Michelin-standard cooking, but it serves up big hearty portions of delicious Hong Kong style dishes. There are a lot of tables within the restaurant but all the tables are very close to each other. Be prepared to share some personal space! Kam Po Kitchen offers sit-down meal service or a take-out line for those who wish to bring home roast duck, soy sauce chicken or any meat of the sort. 

I have tried a number of the dishes offered here. Roast duck over rice, duck wonton soup and prawn with egg chow fun are all good choices. Everything is also inexpensive. Unlike many of the butcher shops in Chinatown, Kam Po does not skimp out on the meat. I have tried the prawn with egg chow fun dish throughout many Chinese restaurants in Chinatown, and the one here is hands down the best. 

Many of the staff members here don't speak English. Two of the female staff speaks English and provides good service though. The only thing that irks me is that the dining tables are always so greasy or oily from a lack of quality deep cleaning. This is a very popular lunch spot for locals in Chinatown. Kam Po is great for your stomach and easy on your wallet and it's definitely one of my favorite lunch spots in Chinatown! CASH ONLY!

excerpts: If you're looking for cheap but delicious roast duck or pork
this is the place to go.
You can get a giant plate of meat with rice for only $6.50.
The menu can be somewhat daunting
, I believe there's around 140 items, but if you stick with what you know you'll be fine.
Might not be the cleanest place or the friendliest service but it adds to the character.
roast duck.author: Taylor B.
roast duck.review:
If you're looking for cheap but delicious roast duck or pork this is the place to go. You can get a giant plate of meat with rice for only $6.50. 
The menu can be somewhat daunting, I believe there's around 140 items, but if you stick with what you know you'll be fine.
Might not be the cleanest place or the friendliest service but it adds to the character.

excerpts: We ordered a Hainanese Chicken and Rice dish as well as a Roast Duck Wonton Noodle Soup bowl.
The wonton soup bowl was a generous portion size, with a large amount of roast duck and several large fresh tasting wontons.
The Hainanese Chicken was tender and the green onion topping was flavorful.
Both were excellent and at a very good price.
The restaurant also served complimentary hot tea.
Service was efficient and the restaurant was clean.
Plenty of indoor seating.
Parking can be difficult to find however.
Overall definitely worth a visit.
The wonton soup bowl was a generous portion size, with a large amount of roast duck and several large fresh tasting wontons.
The Hainanese Chicken was tender and the green onion topping was flavorful.
Both were excellent and at a very good price.
The restaurant also served complimentary hot tea.
Service was efficient and the restaurant was clean.
Plenty of indoor seating.
Parking can be difficult to find however.
Overall definitely worth a visit.
roast duck.author: Tina D.
roast duck.review: Came here around 10:30am on a cold gloomy day looking for some comfort food. We ordered a Hainanese Chicken and Rice dish as well as a Roast Duck Wonton Noodle Soup bowl. The wonton soup bowl was a generous portion size, with a large amount of roast duck and several large fresh tasting wontons. The Hainanese Chicken was tender and the green onion topping was flavorful. Both were excellent and at a very good price. The restaurant also served complimentary hot tea. Service was efficient and the restaurant was clean. Plenty of indoor seating. Parking can be difficult to find however. Overall definitely worth a visit.

excerpts: Awesome takeout roast duck and pork.
No English or credit cards allowed.
We pointed, paid, and tried to be friendly and were met with some deadpan looks that will stay with me.
I almost felt...unwelcome.

I stupidly mentioned that we had found them on yelp and we had come all the way from LA to try their duck, and the look they gave me made me feel that I had just pissed all over their grandmothers grave.
roast duck.author: Kyung E.
roast duck.review:
Awesome takeout roast duck and pork. No English or credit cards allowed. We pointed, paid, and tried to be friendly and were met with some deadpan looks that will stay with me. I almost felt...unwelcome. I stupidly mentioned that we had found them on yelp and we had come all the way from LA to try their duck, and the look they gave me made me feel that I had just pissed all over their grandmothers grave. Ok, so not friendly but the food...

Awesome; we ordered a half duck and a half pound of roast pork for about $25. Both so very good, my mouth is watering thinking about it. The pork skin was crispy and delicious, even cold. 

We took our loot to the hotel room and snacked over the course of a few hours. At no point did it turn and not taste absolutely amazing. Can't wait to come back! Awesome meat for a great price.

excerpts: While my roast duck was delicious and moist, my husband's was dry and his wontons had a very unpleasant taste.
The stained plastic dishes and sticky tables made the overall atmosphere poor.
If the food had been excellent, we could have overlooked that.
Unfortunately, we had a bad experience and would not return.
roast duck.author: Marie S.
roast duck.review: I have a very mixed opinion of Kam Po that ultimately leans negative. While my roast duck was delicious and moist, my husband's was dry and his wontons had a very unpleasant taste. The stained plastic dishes and sticky tables made the overall atmosphere poor. If the food had been excellent, we could have overlooked that. Unfortunately, we had a bad experience and would not return.

excerpts: It had the roast duck decorations and the jam packed dining room.
Cue the order for bbq pork, chicken chow mein, fried rice, bbq short ribs, roast duck, Mongolian beef, and kung pao chicken.
Everything was succulent but maybe a tad heavy on the salty side.
I feel like I gained 10 lbs in one meal
but I couldn't stop.
roast duck.author: Cam M.
roast duck.review:
During my family's quick stay in San Francisco, it became our purpose to find great Cantonese food. Online Kam Po had great reviews, in person it looked like any other restaurant in Chinatown. It had the roast duck decorations and the jam packed dining room. Our eyes grew larger than our stomachs when we saw that most plates were under $6. 

Cue the order for bbq pork, chicken chow mein, fried rice, bbq short ribs, roast duck, Mongolian beef, and kung pao chicken. Everything was succulent but maybe a tad heavy on the salty side. I feel like I gained 10 lbs in one meal but I couldn't stop. Even my family the picky eaters were in love with this place. 

My only cons were that the Mongolian beef was more onions than beef and don't expect to have your own table. We shared ours with other customers. The restaurant can fill up but we didn't mind. 

This location is a bit off from Chinatown which helped us find parking as well. I did notice a lot of customers ordering different variations of their noodle soups. They looked and smelled delicious. Hopefully someone else has reviewed them.

excerpts: I highly recommend getting the Roast Duck and BBQ Pork Rice dish.
The portion size is very large and filling, and I would suggest either sharing the plate with another person or being prepared to bring back some leftovers.
roast duck.author: Yuan J.
roast duck.review:
Kam Po Kitchen is the perfect place to grab a delicious and cheap dinner. The restaurant offers a variety of different meats to go with their soups, rice plates, and porridges. 

I highly recommend getting the Roast Duck and BBQ Pork Rice dish. The portion size is very large and filling, and I would suggest either sharing the plate with another person or being prepared to bring back some leftovers. The meats themselves are very well-cooked and super flavorful, but the best part about the dish was that it was less than $10.

Do note that this place is quite no-frills, so keep your expectations for the service low and just come here for the great food!

excerpts: My go-to items are their chow fun, roast duck, roast pork, and wonton soup.
roast duck.author: Camille L.
roast duck.review:
I LOVE this place. 

It's very convenient to call your order in ten minutes prior, illegally park, then run in to grab your bags of enough food to survive for the next two days, all
for something like $20! 

My go-to items are their chow fun, roast duck, roast pork, and wonton soup.

Sweet customer service goes a long way, too.

excerpts: We had the oh so delicious barbecued roast pork/roast duck (which sold out shortly after we ordered ours), prawns with salt & pepper, and water spinach with preserved tofu.
The roast pork was so crispy!!
Mmmmm.
There's so much on this menu that you'll be sure to find the Chinese dish that you're looking for!
And the prices are not too shabby at all!
My parents have been here as well
so it's a family fave.
Will definitely be coming back for more!
roast duck.author: Monissa W.
roast duck.review: My brother took me here because he knows how much I love BBQ delicacies! Oh man, delicious! We had the oh so delicious barbecued roast pork/roast duck (which sold out shortly after we ordered ours), prawns with salt & pepper, and water spinach with preserved tofu. The roast pork was so crispy!! Mmmmm. There's so much on this menu that you'll be sure to find the Chinese dish that you're looking for! And the prices are not too shabby at all! My parents have been here as well so it's a family fave. Will definitely be coming back for more!

excerpts: Pretty good roast duck and BBQ Pork
that's similar to several spots in Oakland's China town.
A little bit of each (but enough for a a meal) came out to $9 out the door which by SF standards is excellent.
You can order to go or eat in the restaurant itself which seats I'd say around 30 ish people.
roast duck.author: Rod M.
roast duck.review: Pretty good roast duck and BBQ Pork that's similar to several spots in Oakland's China town.  A little bit of each (but enough for a a meal) came out to $9 out the door which by SF standards is excellent. You can order to go or eat in the restaurant itself which seats I'd say around 30 ish people.

excerpts: YOU WILL NEVER WANT TO PAY MORE THAN 10 BUCKS FOR ROAST DUCK
AGAIN​.
The chow mein was also pretty amazing.
I wish we got more stuff
because​ their menu has an absolutely​ insane spread of dishes (I think we counted like 100+ items).
I'm​
coming back here whenever I'm in the city.
Great place to eat after day drinking.
Cash only though
roast duck.author: Matthew W.
roast duck.review:
DO NOT COME HERE. YOU WILL NEVER WANT TO PAY MORE THAN 10 BUCKS FOR ROAST DUCK AGAIN​. The chow mein was also pretty amazing. I wish we got more stuff because​ their menu has an absolutely​ insane spread of dishes (I think we counted like 100+ items). I'm​ coming back here whenever I'm in the city. Great place to eat after day drinking. Cash only though but almost everything is so reasonably​ priced you could put yourself and your date in a diabetic coma for 40 bucks.


I've since returned (while sober even) and the food was still great. The roast pork is also fantastic, same with the fried rice with with scrambled egg and shrimp ( get it with the gravy)

excerpts: I get the combo - duck with bbq pork over rice and sometimes, I get the roast duck wonton rice noodles.
Come and visit soon
roast duck.author: Jsphn T.
roast duck.review:
This is gets busy during lunchtime or else you have to stand there and wait. The hot food to go line is decent.
The menu prices is reasonable . I get the combo - duck with bbq pork over rice and sometimes, I get the roast duck wonton rice noodles. Come and visit soon

excerpts: Their congee was only $3.50 and the roast duck and wonton noodle soup about $7.
I mean, geez, we were stuffed with a total check amount of less than $12!
roast duck.author: Christina L.
roast duck.review:
I will admit, for value and convenience Kam Po cannot be beat! They were open at 9:30 am on a Saturday when I woke up in a daze with a hankering for noodle soup. Their congee was only $3.50 and the roast duck and wonton noodle soup about $7. I mean, geez, we were stuffed with a total check amount of less than $12! For these reasons, I do recommend Kam Po and will probably be back...only when it's the only option available.

The preserved duck egg and pork had good flavor but the pork had that weird off taste of lower end Chinese restaurants. The duck was good but the noodle soup and wontons were otherwise lacking in flavor.

Great stop to stop by when you're looking for a quick, cheap bite, otherwise there are definitely other options nearby.

excerpts: I got the roast duck rice noodles ($6.25).
The soup was amazing (the magic of MSG, i think LOL this assumption is not verified
but it tasted like it).
I was stuffed afterward.
Honestly i was so happy the entire time i was eating.
roast duck.author: Jen K.
roast duck.review:
honestly yall idk why people be trippin over service quality. the nonchalance is kinda just a part of the Chinese food culture and adds to the authenticity. Besides the service was fine when i went. The workers were eating when we came in to sit, but server still came to serve us and took our order and etc. 

Anyway, I LOVE THIS PLACE. I was raised in Hong Kong and this place totally brings back memories. If you want authentic taste, this is it. If i had to show someone what i usually eat in hk, id take them to this place. Andddd this is what they call "best value". you get a good amount of food for the price you pay, and its so tastyyy! Total GOOD DEAL.

I got the roast duck rice noodles ($6.25). The soup was amazing (the magic of MSG, i think LOL this assumption is not verified but it tasted like it). I was stuffed afterward. Honestly i was so happy the entire time i was eating. I WOULD DEFINITELY COME BACK.

and remember, CASH ONLY.

excerpts: The roast duck was also delicious.
We also had seafood tofu clay pot and the beef stew noodle.
Everything hit the spot after a nice long walk.
We'll be back when we're in town again!
roast duck.author: Clifford M.
roast duck.review: Great pricing and it tasted like homemade Chinese, but better! The roast pork belly was really good and had a really crispy skin, definitely the best part. The roast duck was also delicious. We also had seafood tofu clay pot and the beef stew noodle. Everything hit the spot after a nice long walk. We'll be back when we're in town again!

excerpts: I had the Herbal & Pig Liver Soup & Roast Duck and Roast Pork over Rice.
roast duck.author: Rudy H.
roast duck.review:
one of the most authentic Cantonese kitchen I've been so far.
this place (in terms of ambiance) is a real basic Hong Kong style hole in the wall eatery. 
so, the focus here is the food.
I had the Herbal & Pig Liver Soup & Roast Duck and Roast Pork over Rice.

if you don't speak any Cantonese, just pretend that you're a tourist somewhere in Hong Kong being stranded in alleyways somewhere in Mong Kok, Yau Ma Tei or Sam Shui Po.

big menu, generous portions, hearty and delicious.
I really like this place. 

by the way, it's cash only.

excerpts: I love to order the combo plate: half bbq pork and half roast duck rice plate.
They give large portions of food for a low price.
They've been around for at least 30 years serving the community, got to appreciate how they keep their prices low too!
roast duck.author: lydia m.
roast duck.review: This a great place to eat traditional Chinese BBQ. I love to order the combo plate: half bbq pork and half roast duck rice plate. They give large portions of food for a low price. They've been around for at least 30 years serving the community, got to appreciate how they keep their prices low too!

excerpts: Ordered roast duck and rice to go ($7.50).
Service was fast.
Duck was absolutely delicious - just the right amount of saltiness and fat.
roast duck.author: Siv L.
roast duck.review:
Ordered roast duck and rice to go ($7.50).  Service was fast.  Duck was absolutely delicious - just the right amount of saltiness and fat.  Rice was way more than enough.  

I originally wanted 2 meats and rice but the man behind the counter didn't hear me well and I didn't bother to correct him once I saw how much duck I was getting and how good it looked.

Will definitely be back!

excerpts: Got a two item combo- roast duck and bbq pork over rice $9.
I was amazed at the portion.
It was huge.
Thankfully, i was hungry.
You also get a complimentary bowl.of soup with your meal.
roast duck.author: Reese D.
roast duck.review:
Extremely great value for money. Kam Po is slightly out of the way from the main street of Chinatown. I was there after the lunch rush, so no problem getting a seat.

Got a two item combo- roast duck and bbq pork over rice $9. I was amazed at the portion. It was huge. Thankfully, i was hungry. You also get a complimentary bowl.of soup with your meal. definitely value for money.

I asked for duck breast and lean pork- which was what I got. Bonus point. Taste wise, it was on the bland side. The duck wasn't crispy - the skin was soggy but the bbq pork had a nice flavor. The tiny hole  in the wall place also appeared to be clean. No greasy table, which is A++

They have a variety on the menu - wanton noodles,  claypot rice and stews, as well as stir fried noodles. Definitely give this place a try.

excerpts: We had their roast duck, roast pork, pork fried rice, shrimp fried rice, shrimp wonton soup, and their Chinese broccoli.
Everything was delicious!
For a party of 6, we only paid $57.
roast duck.author: Anna D.
roast duck.review:
If you want to dive into the Chinese culture and surroundings, you must come to Kam Po to eat. We first came here about 10 years ago and have been waiting for the day when we would come back to eat here. It is exactly as I remembered. 

It's a little intimidating when you first walk in here. The customers are mostly local Chinese and a few others who have braved the parking and the streets to try out their food. Don't expect 5 star dining or service. This is a no frills place - you come in, sit down, order and eat. Cash only, by the way. 

We stayed a total of 5 days here in San Francisco, and of all the places we've eaten, this is the one we talked about the most. We had their roast duck, roast pork, pork fried rice, shrimp fried rice, shrimp wonton soup, and their Chinese broccoli. Everything was delicious! For a party of 6, we only paid $57. Most, if not all of their dishes are $6-$8.

After returning from our trip, we were craving Kam Po food, so we ordered from our go-to Chinese restaurant, and nothing comes close. I guess we're going to have to wait for another trip to SF for a visit!

excerpts: Nice little roast duck and pork restaurant.
Roast duck wonton egg noodle soup is grub.
The garlic pea sprouts is really tasty.
roast duck.author: Andy V.
roast duck.review: Nice little roast duck and pork restaurant. Roast duck wonton egg noodle soup is grub. The garlic pea sprouts is really tasty. Roast pork is just average. It's a tiny place but service is fast. They only accept cash.

excerpts: TWO BBQ ITEMS WITH RICE - Roast Duck and Roast Pork...
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kam-po-kitchen-san-francisco?select=ZZTE_asvtu5sg-Ilq7tgzQ

)
Compared to my go-to for Chinese BBQ (Cheung Hing), Kam Po holds up pretty well!
While some of the skin could have been crispier, the cut of Roast Pork was fairly thick and didn't have a ton of fat on it.
As for the duck, it was just as good as what I had as a kid - very juicy, luscious, and oh so tender.
roast duck.author: Mike L.
roast duck.review:
While not to the same extent as other parts of the city (hello, Mission), Chinatown has seen its fair share of changes over the years.  Unfortunately (for me), it seems that a lot of those changes have involved the restaurants my relatives and I used to frequent.  Great Wall, Pacific Court Cafe...all gone.  Thank goodness Kam Po is still around though.  It's been a while since I've been back, but my first trip here was over 20 years and they're still going strong!

Stepping inside, Kam Po likely won't impress, save for the tasty looking rack of roasted pork, ducks, and chickens next to the counter (https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kam-po-kitchen-san-francisco?select=GOlu69zPbWbawS0Moe9L2g)  The place is somewhat small, the floors aren't exactly spic-and-span, and the tables have obvious signs of wear and tear.  However, the menu and, more importantly, the food do not disappoint.  The range of offerings may not amaze, but the quality, as well as the cheap prices, definitely stand out!

-- HAINANESE CHICKEN WITH RICE...$5.55
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kam-po-kitchen-san-francisco?select=IMKRS_R8gTerP666h8K6Vg)
Such a large portion for such a tiny price!  The chicken was meaty, tender, and moist and they certainly didn't skimp on the garlic sauce (poured on top rather than on a separate dish).  Plus, there was a lot of pickled vegetables too!  As good as everything was though, I wish the rice itself had a stronger taste of chicken and ginger to it.

-- TWO BBQ ITEMS WITH RICE - Roast Duck and Roast Pork...$8.30
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kam-po-kitchen-san-francisco?select=ZZTE_asvtu5sg-Ilq7tgzQ)
Compared to my go-to for Chinese BBQ (Cheung Hing), Kam Po holds up pretty well!  While some of the skin could have been crispier, the cut of Roast Pork was fairly thick and didn't have a ton of fat on it.  As for the duck, it was just as good as what I had as a kid - very juicy, luscious, and oh so tender.  Plus, the sauce they pour on the meat and rice is so delicious!

Admittedly, had I been on the fence with how many stars to give, I likely would have been a little more generous simply because of all of the memories I have from coming here as a kid (it's been a family favorite ever since my grandfather had moved to Chinatown).  However, I can honestly say I didn't have to in this case.  Sure, I can see why some might not be as enthused as I am, but we've never had any problems here and the food (and value) more than warrant the four star rating.

Thanks, Kam Po, for the delicious comfort food and trip down memory.  Here's to you guys sticking around for another 20+ years!

excerpts: Was really, and I mean REALLY, looking forward to roast duck.
We ordered the roast duck wanton noodles ( turned out to be soup) and roast pork and rice.
Soup and wanton were flavorful.
I wish there were meatier pieces of duck.
The bbq pork was all fat and scarce on meat.
And so the search for good roast duck continues.
roast duck.author: Joanne N.
roast duck.review:
Was really, and I mean REALLY, looking forward to roast duck. Expectations were high thanks the four stars this place has here on yelp and also cause the roast ducks hanging by the front window made it seem legit. 

We ordered the roast duck wanton noodles ( turned out to be soup) and roast pork and rice. Soup and wanton were flavorful. I wish there were meatier pieces of duck. The bbq pork was all fat and scarce on meat. So all in all, ate a ton of carbs here. 

Service was friendly hence the 3 stars. Also the noodles were pretty good tho not what I came for. And so the search for good roast duck continues.

excerpts: Roast duck rice - 3 stars.
The roast duck was not bad although I think I've had better elsewhere in the city.
roast duck.author: Lindt C.
roast duck.review:
Appears to be an authentic Chinese restaurant. 

We had the following for lunch:

Century egg porridge - 4 stars. I've been looking for hearty Cantonese 'zhok' for some time and this hit the spot. It was not too salty and the pork was seasoned just right. Real comfort food in cold weather. 

Roast duck rice - 3 stars. The roast duck was not bad although I think I've had better elsewhere in the city. 

Roast pork noodles - 2 stars. The roast pork had a thin smooth crust which wasn't what we were looking for. I guess we envisioned the dim sum roast pork version with the crackled skin. The noodles were very dry and the cabbage was unfortunately not well-cooked. 

I wanted to like this place since it came with a bit of hype but the roast meats did not live up to expectations for a roast meats restaurant. But portions were huge and very good value for money. I saw a neighbouring table having egg horfun and may try that next time. 

Cash only.

excerpts: My usual is a big plate of roast duck and crispy roast pork over rice for $8.30.
Easily good for two people.
Beef Chow Fun was $5.95 which usually goes for 8 to 11 bucks elsewhere.
Remember old people and blue collar workers are indicating of good plentiful food at a very reasonable price.
roast duck.author: Laurence C.
roast duck.review: Like all things prices goes up but this place still offers one of the best chinese bbq in town at a reasonable price. Remember this is a place to get fed for a cheap price so don't expect fancy surroundings or service. My usual is a big plate of roast duck and crispy roast pork over rice for $8.30. Easily good for two people. Beef Chow Fun was $5.95 which usually goes for 8 to 11 bucks elsewhere.  Remember old people and blue collar workers are indicating of good plentiful food at a very reasonable price.

excerpts: I ordered the roast duck noodle soup, which came as expected.
I wasn't a big fan of the dumplings, but the duck, broth, and noodles more than made up for that.
We had so much food leftover, we decided to take it home for dinner.
Great value and super good.
roast duck.author: Mabel J.
roast duck.review: My husband and I came here after seeing all the great Yelp reviews and it didn't disappoint. We got in around 3pm and it wasn't packed, but wasn't empty. Service was a little slow, but we weren't in a rush after walking up from Union Square. A nice leisurely late lunch was what we wanted. Portions were super big, which made sense why it was all families and groups besides us. This is the only congee I've ever had that tastes like my Aunt's arroz caldo. It would be exactly like my Aunts if I could still see full rice kernels and if the skin was still on the chicken. Be careful when you order roast pork, it is the crunchy lechon style pork hanging by the counter, not the BBQ style pork in the front window. That is what they call BBQ pork. I ordered the roast duck noodle soup, which came as expected. I wasn't a big fan of the dumplings, but the duck, broth, and noodles more than made up for that. We had so much food leftover, we decided to take it home for dinner. Great value and super good.

excerpts: We order the usual roast duck/BBQ pork rice plates, and boss lady hustles over with a pot of tea on our table and voila!
Often times, there's also soup on the house.
If you order any clay pots, order immediately, as they take longer than roast duck or any other rice/noodle/vegetable dish.
roast duck.author: Christine R.
roast duck.review:
Boss lady does not play here, you better know what you want before sitting down.  We don't even ask for menus anymore, ain't nobody got time for that!  Been coming here the last two decades since they opened.  My uncle said they remodeled the interior last year, still looks the same to me.  We order the usual roast duck/BBQ pork rice plates, and boss lady hustles over with a pot of tea on our table and voila!  Often times, there's also soup on the house.  Within minutes, plates of food arrives, and everyone digs in as if we've been famished for weeks. 

I've also seen her chop up the meats for take-out; she does it all I tell ya!  The chefs are inside cooking and wrestling with gigantic woks, ensuring your food comes out super hot & fresh.  Watch out Martin Yan j/k lol.  This place is definitely a hole-in-the-wall if you want some awesome Chinese food.  Not only is it cheap, you can feed the entire family and still bring leftovers home for lunch the next day.  Everyone goes home happy with a fuller tummy.

P.S.  If you order any clay pots, order immediately, as they take longer than roast duck or any other rice/noodle/vegetable dish.

excerpts: I usually get the roast duck and crispy pork over rice, which comes with a bit of cabbage.
The portion sizes are insanely large!
For 9 dollars, the amount of food i got could legitimately feed a family of four.
Not an exaggeration.
I felt like I got 3-4 pounds worth of total food.
roast duck.author: Patrick J.
roast duck.review:
Wow!  I have come here four to five time now and am never disappointed.  I usually get the roast duck and crispy pork over rice, which comes with a bit of cabbage.  The portion sizes are insanely large!  For 9 dollars, the amount of food i got could legitimately feed a family of four.  Not an exaggeration.  I felt like I got 3-4 pounds worth of total food.  The meat is really tasty, and the sauce the butcher pours over everything is very savory.

The butcher is a really legit looking Cantonese guy that wields his massive blade with great efficiency while appearing lackadaisical and chatting up the locals. Pretty cool local feel inside.  Not many tourists/non-locals to be found.

excerpts: The wonton soup with roast duck was okay.
Good wontons.
Okay roast duck.
roast duck.author: Jean K.
roast duck.review: The bbq pork is still the way to go. I know their roast pork is supposed to be famous but at Saturday lunchtime it was not great - dry meat, hard skin (not crispy hard, but hard hard). The wonton soup with roast duck was okay. Good wontons. Okay roast duck.

excerpts: I love the roast duck on rice, which comes with some cabbage and an entire plate of rice.
You really can't go wrong with any of the bbq options.
roast duck.author: Elisa L.
roast duck.review:
Flip to the back page and order one of the rice dishes. For the extremely fair prices (mostly $5.10), the portions are gigantic. I love the roast duck on rice, which comes with some cabbage and an entire plate of rice. You really can't go wrong with any of the bbq options. If you stay to eat, you get soup as well.

Service is very quick whether you take to go or eat in, though there is often a lineup at the front for togo orders, don't make the mistake of trying to order it without waiting in line. If you go in to eat by yourself, expect to share a table. If you are seated near the take out counter, expect customers to be temporarily putting their belongings on your table trying to recollect themselves before they leave to head out, because the restaurant is quite crowded and there really isn't anywhere else to do that.

The wait staff are busy so the best tactic is to put the money on the table so it's ready to go for the bill. Sometimes if they recognize you, they don't even bring you a menu, probably assuming you know what you want, so you have to be ready for that too. 

Of course the service isn't that great and the interior isn't the cleanest - what do you expect from a Chinese restaurant with such reasonable prices? I love coming here for quick 20min meals.

excerpts: As far as I can tell, the roast duck I got at Kam Po was a faithful interpretation of the duck dish iterated upon and canonized several centuries ago in China.
roast duck.author: Dian J.
roast duck.review:
As far as I can tell, the roast duck I got at Kam Po was a faithful interpretation of the duck dish iterated upon and canonized several centuries ago in China. In other words, it was hella good.

SF is blessed with many a cheap and tasty restaurant - but Kam Po edges out the competition with borderline uncompetitive prices and non-soul-crushing wait times. 

More and more people are starting to flock to this restaurant and its giant, glistening pieces of poultry hanging by the window. Regardless, I'll be back for more of that dank duck meat.

excerpts: Ordered the roast duck in wonton noodle soup ($7) but unfortunately 10 minutes into making it they told me they didn't have roast duck anymore and asked if roast pork was fine.
It wasn't really the best alternative but it was still good too.
The soup broth and wontons really made up for it.
roast duck.author: Linda X.
roast duck.review:
CASH ONLY

This is one of my favorite spots for cheap Chinese food! Don't expect anything fancy or the service to be overly friendly and attentive. Yes the server throws menus at you when you sit and you might have to flag them down if you want something but it's all part of the local Chinatown experience. It's more about good cheap food in large quantities.

Ordered the porridge with preserved egg ($3.50). It was served in a massive bowl and was enough for 2 people by itself. Personally I LOVE this dish. It feels so homey and filling. I took my friend who had never had preserved egg before and he really didn't like it so it's definitely an acquired taste.

Ordered the roast duck in wonton noodle soup ($7) but unfortunately 10 minutes into making it they told me they didn't have roast duck anymore and asked if roast pork was fine. It wasn't really the best alternative but it was still good too. The soup broth and wontons really made up for it. You get this giant bowl enough for 2 people on its own!

Overall go for the food and prices not the service.

excerpts: This is my go to spot for crispy BBQ pork and roast duck.
They do roast duck extremely well.
The bites are juicy and tender and never seems to get dry.
roast duck.author: Victor N.
roast duck.review:
This is my go to spot for crispy BBQ pork and roast duck. They do roast duck extremely well. The bites are juicy and tender and never seems to get dry. It looks like they pour some sauce or oil over it to make it even more moist. 

Don't expect service to be anything great. They get you the food and that's all that matters.

excerpts: We got salt and pepper prawns, roast duck, cod with Chinese broccoli, American broccoli with garlic sauce and bbq pork fried rice.
roast duck.author: Lei H.
roast duck.review:
It is cheap for sure but you get what you pay for.  Food was okay but cheap.  We got salt and pepper prawns, roast duck, cod with Chinese broccoli, American broccoli with garlic sauce and bbq pork fried rice.  

Duck was greasy and unimpressive.  Waitress tried to push the half duck.  Thank god I didn't get it.    Prawns was tasty but overly oily.   Same with fish.  Western broccoli and fried rice was decent. 

I give it 3 stars for the price and speed of service.   Won't be back any time soon and definitely not for dinner again.  


Place feels not clean and there is no service to discuss - typical Chinese fast food service.

excerpts: But we ordered roast duck, roast pork, bbq pork, pork intestines, chicken feet, &soy sauce chicken.
When we got home tonight, we had a feast!
roast duck.author: Lihz P.
roast duck.review:
Fairly cheap. Big portions. Quick service! Always packed! So not really great for big groups unless you're willing to wait..

Came in today with my family (party of 10) around 2:30pm and there were no tables open so we waited a good 20-25 minutes before a table opened up. The staff was very nice and quick to let us know it'll be a while until we were seated which was no problem because only half of us were there first. 
--Minus 1 star for all the people who came in after us and seated themselves at random tables instead of waiting to be seated.--
By the time the rest of the party was there it only took us about 5 more minutes until we were seated.

Onto the food... We decided to do family style dinner, so we ordered wonton soup, seafood tofu soup, salted fish fried rice, pan fried house noodles, beef chow fun, roasted pork belly, Garlic Chinese broccoli, garlic water spinach and fish with sweet corn over rice, all to share amongst each other. Everything was really good and our tummies were satisfied! The dish that stood out the most to me was the fish w sweet corn! It sounded weird at first, but don't knock it til you try it!

Obviously, since they sell fresh af Chinese bbq in store as well, we had to buy some to bring home for family dinner! Sadly they didn't have oxtail.. But we ordered roast duck, roast pork, bbq pork, pork intestines, chicken feet, &soy sauce chicken. When we got home tonight, we had a feast! Ate all that with side of baguettes & soy sauce, Vietnamese style! 

This is always my family's go to lunch spot when we're in Chinatown SF. We'll be back soon!

excerpts: Really good Chinese BBQ (char siu, roast park, roast duck).
Their other dishes are really good too and very reasonably priced.
Highly recommended!
roast duck.author: howie f.
roast duck.review: Really good Chinese BBQ (char siu, roast park, roast duck). Their other dishes are really good too and very reasonably priced. Highly recommended!

excerpts: Came here for dinner seeking some roast duck.
We left stuffed with duck, noodles, bitter melon, BBQ pork (char siu), wontons...
The roast duck over rice is a good deal.
Not only does it feel like you're served half a duck, but it's also really tasty!
The flavor seemed pretty great and the meat was juicy.
The skin wasn't super crisp and on the fattier side, but I kinda like it that way.
You can also get the roast duck in a bowl of won ton noodles - you get a lot of duck and wonton dumplings, but the skin isn't crispy..
roast duck.author: Lydia N.
roast duck.review:
Classic Chinatown! I didn't know places like this still existed! (Certainly not that I've seen Seattle). Everything on the menu is ~ $7 or less. Cash only. Giant portions. They speak Canto. There's hanging roast meats (duck & pork) in the window. So many soup noodles. 

Came here for dinner seeking some roast duck. We left stuffed with duck, noodles, bitter melon, BBQ pork (char siu), wontons... The roast duck over rice is a good deal. Not only does it feel like you're served half a duck, but it's also really tasty! The flavor seemed pretty great and the meat was juicy.  The skin wasn't super crisp and on the fattier side, but I kinda like it that way. You can also get the roast duck in a bowl of won ton noodles - you get a lot of duck and wonton dumplings, but the skin isn't crispy.. the addition of won ton dumplings (they're just ok, a little starchy and dense) isn't worth soggy duck.  

Char siu (BBQ pork) was definitely homemade and not cloyingly sweet - which I really appreciated. It also isn't bright red like you might find at other restaurants. What you end up with is a natural looking savory BBQ pork, with a hint of sweetness. It's also a bit fatty. Yum!

Veggies - the garlic green beans aren't as garlicky or salty or fried as other places, but it's a simple dish. It's still a bit oily, so I don't know if you actually feel healthier for eating these vegs.  The bitter melon was pretty good though - if you enjoy bitter melon. I found it pretty mild and simply seasoned here.

excerpts: Lastly, like the Chinatown visits of my childhood, roast duck and pork hung in the window and there was a cook with his large cleaver slicing them on his wood stump.
roast duck.author: Lianna N.
roast duck.review:
To me, Kam Po is exactly what you would expect in any Chinatown. It's a bit off the beaten path, and seemed to house more locals than tourists (aka me). When we entered at 2 for a late lunch, there were no tables available, which made me really excited. Secondly, the staff spoke minimal English, so it seemed more authentic than American. Lastly, like the Chinatown visits of my childhood, roast duck and pork hung in the window and there was a cook with his large cleaver slicing them on his wood stump. All of these things just made me break out into a gigantic grin. 

After a bit of a wait and some awkward waving/eye contact attempts, we were seated crammed in a small table. I opted for the beef tendon noodle soup, and my friend went with the duck noodle soup. We ordered a side of crispy roast pork, because he had never tried it before and I was curious if it was as good as the one my grandmother used to make or ones I have eaten out at restaurants throughout life. The pork, I was disappointed. I think they served us some that had been previously cut, so the meat was a little dry and it was cold-ish. The skin was oily but not very crispy, lacking the crackle I love so much. Redemption came in the form of noodles, as we both enjoyed the dishes they brought out. My friend, unaccustomed to Chinese noodle soups, was surprised to see how bland the broth was in comparison to say pho or ramen. I agreed, but this is the style of the Chinese and what I grew up with, so I still love it dearly along with pho and ramen!

Overall, this is a great place simple place to either dine in or carry out. The meat hanging in the window is chopped for you and weighed per pound, so you can come and try all the varieties of pork, chicken, and duck that your heart desires to go. I especially liked their selections of egg and rice noodle soups with meat.

excerpts: Cheap, quick, and tasty Hong Kong style BBQ : roast pork, BBQ pork, roast duck, etc.
Cash only and probably not the cleanest place but tasty and cheap.
roast duck.author: Aaron H.
roast duck.review: Perfect hole-in-the-wall HKG style BBQ place. Cheap, quick, and tasty Hong Kong style BBQ : roast pork, BBQ pork, roast duck, etc. Cash only and probably not the cleanest place but tasty and cheap.

excerpts: I ordered the roast duck and pork with rice which was pretty horrible.
The duck was oily and mostly skin and bones.
To top it all, the restroom was absolutely disgusting.
roast duck.author: Sydney X.
roast duck.review:
I was in the neighborhood and saw the good reviews, so I checked out the place and I was very disappointed. 
The place is very crowded and everyone is loud. The staff are far from friendly, and one lady with short dark hair kept screaming at customers and other staff. Also the chefs didn't wear gloves and they'd touch people's cash and the food again without washing their hands. I had to wait for a very very long time to get my food. I ordered the roast duck and pork with rice which was pretty horrible. The duck was oily and mostly skin and bones. To top it all, the restroom was absolutely disgusting.

excerpts: I ordered the BBQ pork and roast duck.
The pork was too tough and really lacking that glistening sweet glaze that makes BBQ pork really outstanding.
I also think they microwaved my dish
roast duck.author: Cindy W.
roast duck.review:
Meh -- I guess it gets the job done when you're craving meat but I've definitely had better and fresher in NYC. I ordered the BBQ pork and roast duck. The pork was too tough and really lacking that glistening sweet glaze that makes BBQ pork really outstanding. I also think they microwaved my dish but I was too hungry to complain.

The duck was better but still not as tender as I'd like it to be. Their complimentary soup was really good though.

Cheap and filling - $10 + tip for a lot of meat -- and I really was craving meat. But I don't think I would come back. 

CASH only.

excerpts: We picked up 3 entrees - beef noodle soup ($4.65), chow fun ($5.10), and roast duck lo mein ($6.00).
roast duck.author: Laura C.
roast duck.review:
Torn between 3 and 4 stars - main thing keeping me back from 4 stars is the greasiness of the food.  I've been to Kam Po twice - first time was several years ago.  All I could remember from that visit was how greasy the food was.  Decided to give it another shot - and yep, the food is still fairly greasy.  Any hoot, more on that later.

Kam Po is located on one edge of Chinatown, not too far away from the main drag.  Definitely a hole in the wall, and you'll see a good handful of locals coming in and out to pick up some of their BBQ meat items to go.  Seating space is OK - they have enough room for perhaps 8 or 9 parties.  Yes, their selling point is authentic Chinese cuisine and cheap prices.  Rummaging through the menu, you'll see items in the $4.xx to $6.xx range.  We picked up 3 entrees - beef noodle soup ($4.65), chow fun ($5.10), and roast duck lo mein ($6.00).  Our total including tax  and tip was about $20 and our party of 3 left pretty full.  

I would say the portion sizes are about average for a Chinese place.  I was a little disappointed with the noodle soup - amount of noodles wasn't huge (hence, for a party of 3, each person got a small amount of noodles).  The soup tasted OK, but I thought it was odd that the soup was a little on the greasy side as well.  I like my soups to be hot and comforting - not to leave me feeling like I wouldn't need to use any Chapstick for the rest of the day.  Chow fun was also a tad more oily compared to other places - I know it's normally greasy, but Kam Po seems to like to take it up a notch.  Lo Mein was pretty OK - noodles weren't hugely flavorful, but they put in a decent amount of roasted duck (meaty portions, not just bones).  

Service - well, pretty standard for Chinese eatery.  Cleanliness was also on par with your other Asian spots.  

Overall, if you like cheap Chinese food, this is the place.  If you don't like greasy food, this isn't the place.  I wouldn't mind stopping by here again since it's a great place to go if you're on a budget.

excerpts: Whole Peking Duck (roast duck) costs $18.
roast duck.author: Joy M.
roast duck.review:
This place is always packed so I had to try it out. Especially when you live nearby and walk by it everyday.

Whole Peking Duck (roast duck) costs $18. Their prices have gone up since the old yelp reviews. 

Picked this up for my family on Xmas Day and they said it was the best Peking Duck they have ever eatin.

excerpts: They still had plenty of roast duck, chickens, char siu, roast pork, octopus and all those BBQ foods.
However, hot foods were running low by this time.
It contained very few choices.
roast duck.author: Wendy T.
roast duck.review:
Came in around 6PM on a Thursday. They still had plenty of roast duck, chickens, char siu, roast pork, octopus and all those BBQ foods. However, hot foods were running low by this time. It contained very few choices. Therefore, I got half the guay fay chicken and one pound of octopus.

 Guay fay chicken meat was not at all rough, it was indeed very smooth and very tasty. Didn't even need the oily ginger sauce that I almost always use for my chickens because of the blandness. But this was one of the times that I don't need to dip the chicken in the ginger dip and can still manage to eat the white meat parts. 

Octopus, to me, was average. Nothing special. Nothing horrible. However it was definitely fresh. Also, I think this place is the only place in chinatown that sells octopus. Be sure to stop here if your in chinatown and want some octopus(:

excerpts: My son for a huge bowl of congee and my wife for roast duck noodle soup.
Flavor wise profile is so so.
Nothing to really boast about except for the extravagant portion.
roast duck.author: Kevin C.
roast duck.review: I am visiting from NY and I figure the food here would be comparable to NY Chinatown.  You definitely don't come here for the decor or cleaniness.  However the portion they serve is outrageous.  It was so much food for so little price.  I got mapo tofu rice dish which was quite tasty.  My son for a huge bowl of congee and my wife for roast duck noodle soup.  Flavor wise profile is so so.  Nothing to really boast about except for the extravagant portion.

excerpts: The roast duck had an excellent flavor, albeit on the salty side.
A shame it was a little bony too.
roast duck.author: Marc M.
roast duck.review:
The very windy interior is not the best during cold months. We dropped during the evening when it was a little chilly to find their door propped open and vented windows open as if it were a hot summer's day. Good grief, I'm surprised they can even stand the hilly draft blowing napkins on the floor and chilling you to the bone. They did eventually close the door, but it's still a cold restaurant, so don't how up without warm clothes!

Crsipy roast pork was dry and chewy, and the crispy skin was soggy and flavorless. It was actually kind of bad. I would not recommend this.

The roast duck had an excellent flavor, albeit on the salty side. A shame it was a little bony too. As far as the skin and meat go however, it was tasty.

The wonton soup was a light broth with wonton filled with mushrooms and possibly meat. They had a slight woody flavor that we weren't super excited about, but they are ok.

Rice is a ridiculously cheap, light, and flavorless affair. Unless you are jonesing for rice, this is not the place to get it. Flip side is that they I've you a big bowl of the crap for $1.

excerpts: Silky, chicken broth with chewy egg noodles, giant meat filled wontons, and succulent roast duck.
The soy chicken over rice was also one of the best things I've ever eaten in Chinatown.
The chicken was so tender and flavorful, like it had been marinated and roasted all day.
roast duck.author: Fiona Y.
roast duck.review:
It took 15 minutes to take my order with 3 people working because the lady ahead ordered 3 ducks and was super picky about it but that's not their fault I guess.

I got the duck wonton noodle soup and it was amazing. Silky, chicken broth with chewy egg noodles, giant meat filled wontons, and succulent roast duck. The soy chicken over rice was also one of the best things I've ever eaten in Chinatown. The chicken was so tender and flavorful, like it had been marinated and roasted all day. Must try the pork next time. 

If you're a carnivore, this is a must try.

excerpts: My bf and I split shrimp fried rice, roast duck, and bbq pork.
Both meat dishes were perfectly cooked with lots of flavor without being too salty.
roast duck.author: Abby S.
roast duck.review:
Food (4.5/5): My bf and I split shrimp fried rice, roast duck, and bbq pork. Both meat dishes were perfectly cooked with lots of flavor without being too salty. The fried rice wasn't the best I've ever had, but pretty solid.

Service (4/5): I wasn't expecting much, since a lot of reviews mentioned that service was whatever, but everyone was really friendly to us, even though we didn't speak Canto. 

Value (5/5): We left full and with leftovers for $20 total! So worth. Haha we're always on the lookout for cheap and yummy places, and I'm so glad we found this one. Definitely will be back :)

Note - cash only!

excerpts: The Soy Sauce Chicken, Roast Pork and Roast Duck - lean and delicious!
roast duck.author: Bennett W.
roast duck.review:
Black Pepper Beef & Rice is delicious. The rice plate serving portion seemed very generous so it's definitely a nice lunch meal. Service is good and some of the staff members here are friendly. There is also a fair amount of seating available if you plan on eating here.

Overall:
- good food
- good prices
- good service
- positive first experience

I'm definitely making my way back for lunch when I am nearby.

*The Soy Sauce Chicken, Roast Pork and Roast Duck - lean and delicious!

excerpts: Then we stopped by after lunch to get a roast duck to take home.
We stood in line behind the counter, all 3 of us.
When it got to our turn, as soon as I opened my mouth and started speaking Mandarin, the guy behind the counter miraculously found not one, but two take-out orders he needed to work on.
And both of these were sizable orders, compared to our order of just a duck to-go.
This isn't the first time I've been discriminated against in Chinatown because I can't speak Cantonese, but this is definitely one of the most blatant.
Needless to say, we left in disgust, never to ever set foot here again.
roast duck.author: Judy C.
roast duck.review: I went in there with my parents twice today - the first time was to try and get a table for lunch.  It looked like too long of a wait so we left.  Then we stopped by after lunch to get a roast duck to take home.  We stood in line behind the counter, all 3 of us.  When it got to our turn, as soon as I opened my mouth and started speaking Mandarin, the guy behind the counter miraculously found not one, but two take-out orders he needed to work on.  And both of these were sizable orders, compared to our order of just a duck to-go.  This isn't the first time I've been discriminated against in Chinatown because I can't speak Cantonese, but this is definitely one of the most blatant.  Needless to say, we left in disgust, never to ever set foot here again.

excerpts: 1/2 Roast Duck
- Im a huge addict to great roasted duck, from the crispy skin to the moist fatty meat, there's just something comforting about that smell of five spice that sort of reminds me of autumn.
roast duck.author: Alexander C.
roast duck.review:
Seriously amazing down home Chinese cookery! There's not much to be said about the decor, its barely clean but if you look beyond the greasy tables and the stacks of old newspapers you'll find one that Kam Po is probably one of the best Chinese places I've tried in Chinatown. 

1/2 Roast Duck - Im a huge addict to great roasted duck, from the crispy skin to the moist fatty meat, there's just something comforting about that smell of five spice that sort of reminds me of autumn. KPK nailed this down! 

Small Roast Pork - Small really wasn't all that small. Probably a good half pound of killer roast pork that came with rice and a side of pickled cabbage. My thoughts, rich fatty pork, I mean come on, how can it be so good? Even the crunchy skin didn't stand a chance against me and my love for pork.
